chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed public hearing on the proposed FY2025/26 user fee
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing on the proposed FY2025/26 user fee 
schedules; and Consider adopting 19 revised fee schedules by separate 
resolutions amending the exhibits in Chapters 
2.4 and 11 of the Solano 
County Code, revising and establishing various fees, to become effective July 
1, 2025
A - Summary of Proposed FY2025-26 Fee Changes by Departments
B - Fee Schedules and Resolutions
C - Copy of Public Notice
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Anne Putney introduced the item and provided an 
overview of the recommended updates to the county’s user fees.
Page 12
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding increased fees in 
Environmental Health, Administrative Services Manager Sarah Pappakostas 
stated she believes Supervisor Williams was speaking about the boring fees, 
which were increased by at least double, noting that the actual cost is closer to 
four times what the County was currently charging. 
Engineering Manager Mathew Tuggle stated that the State of California mandates 
permits for boring. Mr. Tuggle further stated there was an increase in several 
fees, where the actual cost to provide the service is considerably more than what 
the department has requested, noting that over the years, changes in laws have 
increased the costs associated with the services. 
Director of Resource Management James Bezek stated the department ran a 
comparison with surrounding jurisdictions, and the recommended cost is in line 
with other counties. 
Supervisor Williams requested in the future, staff provide more information 
regarding what the impacts of future increases will be. 
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments from
the public.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2025-80 through Resolution No. 2025-98 revising fee 
schedules and amending the exhibits in Chapters 2.4 and 11 of the Solano 
County Code, revising and establishing various fees, to become effective July 
1, 2025. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-80 through Resolution No. 2025-98
42

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed Public Hearing to consider adoption of an ordinance for
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed Public Hearing to consider adoption of an ordinance for 
Zone Text Amendment ZT-25-01 to amend Chapter 28 of the Solano County 
Code to revise and update sections pertaining to Office of County Surveyor 
review, 
private 
road 
maintenance 
agreements, 
agricultural 
accessory 
buildings and farm stands in unincorporated Solano County; the project is 
exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) pursuant to 
§15061(b)(3) of CEQA Guidelines
A - Draft Ordinance (Clean)
B - Draft Ordinance (Redline)
C - Public Notice
D - Draft Solano County Road Improvement Standards relating to Private Roa
E - Civil Code Section 845
F - Draft Farm Stand Permitting Guide
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Planning Program Manager Allan Calder provided an overview of the proposed 
amendments to Chapter 28 of the Solano County Code. 
County Surveyor Chris Ferrucci provided an overview of the recommendation to 
Page 13
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
remove the requirement of private road maintenance agreements, returning the 
code to the same as current state law. 
Mr. Bezek further provided information on the reason for the request to remove 
the requirement for road maintenance agreements, noting that many projects that 
would otherwise be acceptable have not moved forward due to the lack of a road 
maintenance agreement. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding road maintenance 
agreements, Mr. Bezek stated there is a secondary mechanism for citizens to 
deal with disagreements, noting this will take the civil matters out of the hands of 
county staff. 
Supervisor Vasquez thanked staff for their efforts to clean up the code. 
Mr. Calder provided an overview of the changes to sections V through X of the 
proposed ordinance related to farm stands. 
A discussion period was held regarding the percentage rates of products sold at 
farm stands that must be grown or produced in Solano County.
Supervisor Williams commented in support of a consistent percentage of 25% 
throughout the county for the percentage requirement of goods grown or 
produced in Solano County to be sold at farm stands, noting she has concerns 
with fairness. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public to
address the Board on this matter and the following comments were received:
A)
Lisa Howard speaking on behalf of the Suisun Vintners and Growers
Association as well as Larry Balestra of Larry’s Produce, noting Mr. Balestra is
happy with the current requirement for locally grown and produced products of
25% for farm stands in his region. Ms. Howard further requested that the Board
consider removing the statement “does not apply” to the larger farm stands. Ms. 
Howard further requested that the Board consider language that includes
“produced onsite, offsite on land within Solano County, or in direct partnership,” 
noting this provides flexibility but will still ensure at least 25% of the product sold
is grown in Solano County.
B)
Cliff Howard speaking on behalf of the Solano County Farm Bureau
commented on additions to the ordinance related to the onsite growing
requirements, noting the Farm Bureau does not agree with the onsite/offsite
growing requirement that does not apply to farm stands larger than 2500 sq. ft.
Mr. Howard further stated it would be difficult for the Farm Bureau to support a
text amendment that does require produce or ag products to be grown in Solano
County. Mr. Howard further stated that there needs to be a different definition of
farm stands that sell a significant amount of product that is not grown in Solano
County.
Page 14
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
C) Gail Culley commented in support of the changes to the farm stand portion of
the code and had questions regarding clarification on the potential costs related
to road maintenance.
Mr. Bezek stated there are no fees related to road maintenance agreements, 
noting that any project that comes in going forward for subdivisions will need to 
submit a proper road maintenance agreement as per the new Road Standards 
and meet the requirements typical for subdivision applications. 
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing. 
Supervisor Williams restated her recommendation to have a countywide Solano 
grown product percentage requirement of 25% and encouraged the removal of 
exemptions for larger farm stands. Supervisor Williams further recommended 
that staff utilize subject matter experts when doing updates to the code. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if staff has been 
given sufficient direction to clarify the differences in the various farm stands, Mr. 
Calder stated to work in a 25% locally grown number into farm stands over 2,500 
square feet would be acceptable as long as it makes sense for the farmers and 
ranchers.
Mr. Bezek commented on the differences between the words local, Solano 
grown, and regional, noting the Board will need to come to a consensus on a 
term for staff to craft language for the ordinance. 
Mr. Bezek commented on the need for more work with regard to Section IV of the 
proposed ordinance, noting that the changes that are being recommended are 
not under the purview of the public hearing being held at this meeting. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need to add language to the ordinance 
regarding regionalism, recommending the addition of the language “in partnership 
with”, to reflect those growers that may grow product in a neighboring county 
while working with a Solano County grower, or a farmer from Solano County who 
leases land in a neighboring county because the particular crop they desire to 
grow, can not be produced in Solano County. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need for two different ordinances, stating he 
would like to see a clear delineation between the definitions of farm stand and 
local market.
Supervisor W

including 
directly 
addressing 
cities 
regarding 
the 
County’s 
jurisdictional 
responsibilities in the Collinsville area 
A - General Plan Designation Description
B - Collinsville General Plan Special Study Area
Attachments:
Chair Mashburn stated the presentation is being brought forward at the request of 
the Board, noting that it provides the Board and the public with the opportunity to 
hear exactly what is in the General Plan and exactly what is and is not designated 
as approved land uses in the region.
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item and 
provided information on the Collinsville Special Study Area.
Water and Natural Resources Program Manager Misty Kaltreider provided 
information on the Water Dependent Industrial Areas.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Dwight Calloway commented on potential security issues, and in support of
the potential of a shipyard in Collinsville
B) Eunice Mallery commented in opposition to the County working with California
Forever on a potential shipbuilding project in Solano County.
C) Joel Barrilleaux commented in opposition to the County working with California
Forever on a potential shipbuilding project in Solano County.
D) Michael Hayes commented in opposition to a potential shipbuilding project in
Solano County.
E) Jim Bartz commented in opposition to a potential shipbuilding project in Solano
County
F) Jan Bartz commented in opposition to a potential shipbuilding project in Solano
County.
G) Terry Tucker commented in opposition to the County working with California
Forever on a potential shipbuilding project in Solano County.
H) Margaret Anderson commented on the potential impacts of a shipbuilding
project in Solano County.
I) Marilyn Farley commented on the potential impacts of a shipbuilding project in
Solano County
Supervisor Vasquez stated this item is simply a presentation of what is possible 
under the current General Plan. Supervisor Vasquez further stated from his 
perspective, this issue should be taken up during the the General Plan review. 
Page 18
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
J) Former Supervisor Duane Kromm commented on the need for the public to
hear data points related to the depth of the shipping channels in the Collinsville
area and information regarding how much dredging will be required to
accommodate the type of ships they are planning to build.
Supervisor Vasquez stated the first step in this process should be a countywide 
summit, so the cities can state what their future development plans are for the 
next 10-20 years, noting that at some point, this discussion needs to be heard by 
the Board and the public. Supervisor Vasquez further stated that at this time, this 
is no pending application for a project. 
Supervisor Williams commented in support of Supervisor Vasquez’s comments, 
noting she would like more information on potential funding for any projects. 
Supervisor Williams further commented on the need for California Forever to 
work with the county on any potential proposal. Supervisor Williams further stated 
the county should be working with Congressman Garamendi, who is focused 
more heavily on Mare Island, and further noted that she would like the cities to 
allow the county to work through this process. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the need for everyone to wait and see how this 
situation pans out, noting that the Executive Order does not have funding 
attached to it. 
Supervisor James commented on the need to distinguish the difference between 
the Ships Act and the Executive Order.
In response to Supervisor James’s comments, Mr. Bezek stated the Executive 
Order identified goals to bring back maritime opportunities that can align with the 
Collinsville area and the General Plan. Mr. Bezek further stated that there has 
been no analysis as to what that could mean to Solano County because there 
has not been a project brought forward. Mr. Bezek further stated the Ships Act is 
a bipartisan effort that is still in process with goals that are similar to the 
Executive Order but more focused at the national level. Mr. Bezek further stated 
that California Forever has held virtual town halls to describe what they would like 
to see in the Collinsville area, which created a lot of excitement within the cities 
and the media. 
Chair Mashburn stated the County has a landowner that has had some 
controversy surrounding it and there is stigma attached to that name for good or 
bad. Chair Mashburn further stated prior to California Forever owning the land it 
was owned by others, noting that regardless of who owns the land, they will still 
be required to bring any project forward and go through a specific process with 
many regulatory agencies to make the project happen. Chair Mashburn noted that 
once that is complete, they would have to bring the proposal to the county for 
review. Chair Mashburn further stated that this is a valid use of the land per the 
county’s current General Plan. Chair Mashburn further stated he fully supports 
the concept of there being some type of shipbuilding industry or manufacturing 
brought to the Solano County region; however, there is a need to separate the 
Page 19
Solano County

April 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
excitement of the cities over the possibilities from the process,

chunks.item_title: Conduct a public hearing and receive a presentation from the Department of
chunks.text:
Conduct a public hearing and receive a presentation from the Department of 
Human Resources on the status of vacant positions, and recruitment and 
retention efforts as required annually by Government Code Section 3502.3, as 
added by AB2561, effective January 1, 2025 
A - Presentation
B - Position Data
Attachments:
Director of Human Resources Niger Edwards introduced the item and provided 
an overview of the 2025 Position Vacancy Report as required by AB265 and an 
overview of the County’s recruitment efforts. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding what the contributing 
factors are to the 305 days that it takes the County to fill the Senior Public Nurse 
position, Ms. Edwards stated for the Senior Public Health Nurse position, there 
are higher education requirements than the requirements to be a Registered 
Nurse. Ms. Edwards further stated while there have been numerous applicants, 
very few meet the minimum requirements in education and experience and have 
a willingness to take on a position that is public facing. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding if there are services the 
County is unable to provide as a result of the vacant positions, Director of Health 
Page 6
Solano County

May 6, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
and Social Services Emery Cowan stated the County currently depends on 
Locum Tenens to fulfill services. Ms. Cowan stated the County does have 
minimum requirements it must meet, noting the department is using both outside 
contractors and students from Touro University. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding recruitment 
strategies, Ms. Edwards stated Human Resources posts positions not only on 
the County’s website, but also on nationwide job postings and websites for 
professional associations. Ms. Edwards further stated in the past Human 
Resources was passively recruiting by waiting for people to apply; however, the 
department is now working on procedures to actively recruit. 
Supervisor Vasquez thanked Ms. Edwards for the effort the department has put in 
for recruitment. Supervisor Vasquez stated there is a shortage of medical 
professionals all over, noting salary, opportunities for advancement, and private 
vs. public employment are all factors in recruiting issues.
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public to 
address the Board on this matter. The following comments were received:
A) Sandra Wall stated the County is not competitive enough in pay and benefits
to hire and retain employees.
B) Joe Ortiz commented on his current employment situation, noting vacancies
in his department have caused him to be assigned work outside of class and
carrying the responsibilities of roles above his. Mr. Ortiz further stated he is not
alone in this situation as he has watched other employees facing the same issue.
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing. 
Received
18

chunks.item_title: Receive an informational presentation on the Sheriff Office’s ability to provide
chunks.text:
Receive an informational presentation on the Sheriff Office’s ability to provide 
temporary law enforcement assistance to the City of Vallejo; and Provide 
direction 
to 
the 
Sheriff 
regarding 
whether 
to 
proceed 
with 
contract 
discussions to provide temporary law enforcement assistance to the City of 
Vallejo
A - Contract Term Sheet.S.O.Vallejo
B - Response to City of Vallejo
C - SB-1379
Attachments:
Sheriff/Coroner Tom Ferrara introduced the item.
John Robertson, Sheriff’s Office, provided an overview of the current situation in 
the City of Vallejo as it relates to their needs for police services and provided an 
overview of the historical timeline of the work completed by the Sheriff to enable 
the County to provide help to the City of Vallejo. 
Undersheriff Brad Dewall provided an overview of the current level of service 
provided by the Sheriff’s Department in the City of Vallejo in 2024 and provided 
Page 7
Solano County

May 6, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
and overview of the proposal to allow the Sheriff’s Department to provide 
temporary law enforcement assistance to the City of Vallejo.
Director of Administrative Services Lisa Donahue provided an overview of the 
twelve month service costs estimates. 
Sheriff Ferrara provided an overview of the next steps that will need to be taken 
prior to starting services. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding how the Sheriff’s 
Department will handle the positions that were updated in the command 
structures once the contract is over, Sheriff Ferrara stated the County can create 
a limited term promotion or hire a retired Sergeant and Lieutenant to return as a 
retired annuitant.
Chair Mashburn stated he does not want to see a permanent PERS liability for 
the County as a result of this contract. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding the need for coverage 
for when the Sheriff’s Deputies serving the area under the contract have to attend 
court hearings or coverage for requested time off, Undersheriff Dewall stated at 
this time the options are to utilize the existing Sheriff’s Deputies that are already 
in the area or to pay overtime.
A question and answer period was held regarding the compatibility of radio 
services and on what will happen with the equipment that will be purchased at the 
end of the contract. 
Emergency Services Manager Robyn Rains stated the radios that will be installed 
are the same as what is in the County’s Sheriff Deputy vehicles, noting that there 
will be the need for an EBRCSA (East Bay Regional Communications System 
Authority) license, purchased by the City of Vallejo, to access their system. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need for urgency with regard to the timeline 
to ensure everything is complete, noting he would like assurances that the 
County will not be held responsible under the current Department of Justice 
(DOJ) settlement agreement. Chair Mashburn further commented on the need to 
complete discussions between the two labor unions, noting he does not want to 
put the County’s deputies in a position where there becomes animosity between 
the two agencies. Chair Mashburn further emphasized the importance of 
ensuring there will be no negative impact to the residents of the unincorporated 
areas of Solano County.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the ability for the City 
of Vallejo to hire enough officers by the end of the contract, Sheriff Ferrara stated 
he is uncertain if they will be able to hire 40 officers, noting that the City of Vallejo 
has been hiring officers already and the fact that they are up to forty-two officers 
shows progress. 
Page 8
Solano County

May 6, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Williams commented in support of the recommendation, noting that 
this contract will provide the City of Vallejo with the ability to beef up their police 
force. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the ability for the 
City of Vallejo to retrofit the purchased vehicles for their use once the contract is 
complete, Sheriff Ferrara stated it would entail some reprogramming; but it is 
likely they will be able to use them. Sheriff Ferrara further stated the biggest 
hurdle will be to acquire the vehicles and get them retrofitted in time. 
Supervisor Williams asked about the proposed service areas, with Sheriff Ferrara 
stating the reason for the proposed service areas relates to the fact that the 
County is already policing areas of the unincorporated County that are next to the 
proposed service areas.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Vallejo Police Chief Jason Ta commented in support of the recommended
action and stated his office is in agreement with the planned proposed service
model.
B) Vallejo City Council Member Helen Marie Gordan commented in support of
the proposed plan.
C) Vallejo City Council Member Alex Matias commented in support of the
proposed plan.
D) Patricia Hunter speaking on behalf of the NACP commented in support of the
proposed plan.
E) Ken Sarna commented in support of the proposed plan.
F) Vallejo City Council Member Dr. Tonia Lediju speaking on behalf of Mayor for
the City of Vallejo Andrea Sorce commented in support of the proposed plan.
Council Member Dr. Lediju also commented in support of the proposed plan.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if the County is 
legally responsible to provide policing services to the City of Vallejo, County 
Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the County is not legally responsible. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented in support of the recommended action, noting 
while the County does not have a legal obligation to help, it does have a moral 
obligation to help. Supervisor Vasquez further stated he is happy to hear the 
commitment of the Council Members from the City of Vallejo.
County Administrator Bill Eml

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on the status of County Wildfire Prevention Programs
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on the status of County Wildfire Prevention Programs 
and funding
A - Status Update on Wildfire Prevention Programs and Funding
Attachments:
Emergency Services Manager Robyn Rains introduced the item and provided an 
overview of the County’s wildfire prevention and resilience programs. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if a list was 
compiled of resdients who have a pool, to be used as an additional source of 
water during a large fire, Ms. Rains stated she is uncertain if that list was ever 
created and she will follow up with the fire chiefs group.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the cost to the 
County for the Pilot Seasonal Firefighter Program, Ms. Rains stated the actual 
cost was $86,000, noting that the Montezuma Fire District Board did not choose 
to participate in the program.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need to utilize the remaining earmark 
funding on programs like the Seasonal Firefighter Program, which would put 
more actual “boots on the ground” and equipment during wildfires.
In response to Supervisor Vasquez’s comments Ms. Rains stated while she does 
agree that each person has a personal responsibility to be prepared for wildfires, 
that understanding is not held throughout the community. Ms. Rains noted staff is 
attempting to utilize additional funding for outreach; however, there is a definite 
need for educational outreach for wildfire prevention. 
Page 7
Solano County

May 13, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding if “know your zone” 
portion of the website will be more accessible on the new website, Ms. Rains 
stated it is currently available and it will be available on the new website. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding dead tree removal, 
Ms. Rains stated the original plan was to work with the Resource Conservation 
District, which had a grant for dead tree removal, noting that because the grant 
came under “climate”, it is now on hold. Mr. Rains further stated that the 
department is currently working with a private non-profit for dead tree removal on 
private property; however, there are limitations to what they can do. Ms. Rains 
noted that it is difficult to use County Roads department staff, because depending 
on the funding being utilized, the County can only do fuel reduction in the 
right-of-way when it is on private property.
A brief discussion period was held regarding dead tree removal and weed 
abatement. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding where Suisun 
Valley falls into the fire safe councils and if there is funding to help them begin 
one, Ms. Rains stated they currently don’t have a council; however, she is 
working on trying to get one started. Ms. Rains further stated while it does not 
require substantial funding to create a fire safe council, staff can help them, 
further noting the existing fire safe councils are also willing to help. 
Supervisor Brown requested staff alert the Board members when there is going 
to be a scheduled burn for fuel reduction or training. Supervisor Vasquez 
commented in support of Supervisor Brown’s request. 
Received
20

chunks.item_title: Consider introducing an ordinance as required by State law to adopt the
chunks.text:
Consider introducing an ordinance as required by State law to adopt the 
updated 2025 Local Responsibility Area (LRA) Fire Hazard Severity Zones 
(FHSZ) Map from the Office of the State Fire Marshal for the unincorporated 
areas of Solano County
A - 2025 FHSZ Ordinance Solano County
B - LRA Map
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item. 
Building Official Saeed Iravani provided an overview of the 
2025 Local 
Responsibility Area Fire Hazard Severity Zones map program.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding if any homeowner 
has lost their insurance as a result of the changed maps, Mr. Iravani stated he 
does not believe so, noting that insurance companies have their own maps they 
look at when considering coverage. 
A discussion was held regarding the changed map and the new areas affected. 
Page 8
Solano County

May 13, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding how constituents 
can keep their insurance when they are in these fire service areas, Mr. Iravani, 
stated the Calfire maps are simply Fire Hazard Maps, noting insurance 
companies use different modeling and tools, which includes looking at the risks of 
the individual properties. Mr. Iravani further stated they are looking to see what the 
homeowner has done to harden their house to potential wildfires. 
Supervisor Vasquez recommended using the Fire Hazard Maps as an overlay 
when completing the General Plan maps. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
approved the introduction of an ordinance to adopt the updated 2025 Local 
Responsibility Area (LRA) Fire Hazard Severity Zones (FHSZ) Map from the 
Office of the State Fire Marshal for the unincorporated areas of Solano County 
by title only and waived further reading by a majority vote. by title only and 
waived further reading by a majority vote. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.

chunks.item_title: Receive a verbal update from Paragon Government Relations, the County’s
chunks.text:
Receive a verbal update from Paragon Government Relations, the County’s 
federal Legislative Advocates on legislative matters of interest to the County
Principal Management Analyst Matthew Davis introduced the item. 
Federal legislative advocates Hasan Sarsour, Joe Krahn, and Rachel Mackey 
provided an update on information on federal legislation of interest to the County.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding possible 
reductions to In-Home Support Services (IHSS) funding, Ms. Mackey stated she 
does not believe that particular line item will be reduced; however, overall cuts to 
Medicaid will certainly impact IHSS, along with other services that are provided.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding potential reduction of 
funding from Social Security, Ms. Mackey stated that Social Security and 
Medicare are not a part of the Reconciliation packet that is being considered. 
In response to questions from Chair Mashburn regarding the level of funding in 
the Ships Act and if the bill is to update existing facilities or if it will allow for new 
construction, Mr. Sarsour stated he is uncertain what the top-line authorization 
is, but he will follow up with the Board. Mr. Krahn stated he is uncertain if there is 
a top-line authorization, noting much of it will be financed with the trust fund. Mr. 
Sarsour stated, in looking at the provisions of the bill as written, it could be utilized 
for both expansion and new construction.
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding if there is funding within 
the bill to pay for infrastructure that would be required for any type of project, Mr. 
Krahn stated there is no direct funding for local infrastructure. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding previously approved 
FEMA funding to repair a broken pipe on Cordelia Road, Mr. Sarsour stated he 
will follow up with the County’s congressional representative. 
Supervisor Brown commented on concerns over cutbacks in funding for Health 
Page 9
Solano County

May 13, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
and Social Services. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if this bill focuses 
on commercial or naval vessels, Mr. Sarsour stated it is primarily for commercial 
vessels; however, the Senate Armed Services Committee will also be reviewing 
the legislation for the military. 
In response to a question from Supervisor James regarding if there are priority 
projects for the Ships Act and the potential workforce pipeline, Mr. Sarsour stated 
there is no overall priority project. Mr. Sarsour further stated there will be some 
funding available for tuition assistance and regional workforce centers. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the potential loss of funding for the County’s 
public health clinics and IHSS. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the timeline for the 
Ships Act, Mr. Sarsour stated the bill is comprehensive and it will possibly take a 
few years for it to be finalized, noting they could pull certain elements of the bill 
and put them in another vehicle, but there is a ways to go on the full legislation.
Received
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Vasquez wished his daughter a happy birthday..
B) Chair Mashburn stated the Dixon May Fair was a success.

This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda;

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on the Community Investment Fund (CIF) Annual
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on the Community Investment Fund (CIF) Annual 
Grants 
FY2025/26; 
Consider 
approval 
of 
a 
recommendation 
to 
allocate 
$341,237 from the Community Investment Fund One-Time Investments to six 
agencies for a term of July 1, 2025 through June 30, 2026 to address the top 
six human services needs in the County; and Delegate authority to the County 
Administrator, with the concurrence of County Counsel, to execute resulting 
contracts
A - Community Investment Fund Annual Grant Presentation
B - CIF Contract Attachments
Attachments:
Deputy Director of First Five Denise Winters introduced the item and provided 
a brief history of the Community Investment Fund program.
Contracts and Program Manager Yuliana Moreno provided an overview of the 
FY2025/26 One-Time Investments for annual grants. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the Request for Proposals process, and 
stated the panel reviewed everything, noting she wanted to ensure the needs 
of the constituents are met.
On motion of Supervisor Brown, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board: 
1) approved the following Community Investment Fund One-Time Investments:
Crescent Moon Center in the amount of $25,000, Bay Area Community
Resources in the amount of $16,237, Parents by Choice in the amount of
$75,000, Touro University in the amount of $75,000, Food is Free Bay Area in
the amount of $75,000, and Rio Vista CARE in the amount of $75,00 for terms of
July 1, 2025 through June 30, 2026 to address the top six human services needs
in the County; and 2) delegated authority to the County Administrator, with the
concurrence of County Counsel, to execute resulting contracts. So ordered by
a 5-0 vote.
33

chunks.item_title: Consider options for the appointment of two commissioners, one for the
chunks.text:
Consider options for the appointment of two commissioners, one for the 
category of community health clinic representative and one for the category of 
hospital 
representative, 
to 
the 
Partnership 
HealthPlan 
of 
California 
Commission
A - Chapter 7.2 Exhibit A
Attachments:
Assistant County Administrator Debbie Vaughn introduced the item and 
provided a brief background on the Partnership HealthPlan Board of 
Commissioners, noting the Board has a total of three allocated positions on 
this commission which can be filled by four different representative types. Ms. 
Vaughn stated the representative types are Physician Representative, 
Hospital Representative, Director of Health and Human Services, and a 
Community Clinic Representative. Ms. Vaughn noted the current Director of 
Health and Social Services Emory Cowan was appointed to the Director of 
Health and Social Services Representative position in December of 2024, 
leaving three representative types and two vacancies to be filled. Ms. Vaughn 
further stated there are currently three applicants, two of which are for the 
Community Health Clinic Category, and one applicant that can fill either the 
Physician or Hospital Representative role. 
Page 10
Solano County

June 3, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding if he as the Chair 
can appoint two Supervisors to sit on an ad hoc interview committee, County 
Counsel Bernadette Curry stated yes he can.
Chair Mashburn asked for volunteers and Supervisors Brown and James 
stated they would be willing to serve. 
Chair Mashburn appointed Supervisors Brown and James to the ad hoc 
committee to interview the two applicants for the Community Health Clinic 
category. Chair Mashburn opened the floor for a motion for the an 
appointment to the position of either Hospital Representative or Physician 
Representative. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
appointed Dr. Seth Kaufman, MD to the Partnership Health Plan Board of 
Commissioners as the Hospital Representative. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public. 
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor Brown commented on her son's graduation from college.
B) Supervisor Williams requested that this meeting of the Solano County
Board of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of former Contra Costa
County Supervisor Federal Glover.
C) Chair Mashburn commented on two trailer bills to the State Budget which
are related to the Delta, noting they will gut CEQA with regard to any water
project the State desires to put forward and limits litigation against the State or
federal government with regard to issues around the environment when it
comes to water projects. Chair Mashburn further stated there is every
indication that the Governor will use these bills to push through the tunnel
project. Chair Mashburn requested staff return with a presentation by the
County's State lobbyist, with regard to any issues the State's budget will have
on Solano County. Chair Mashburn further stated it is his desire that the
County to an opposition position to the trailer bill, and he will be asking the
cities to also take an opposition position to the trailer bill.
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated staff will return on June 10, 2025.
Supervisor Vasquez requested the federal lobbyist also be included in the 
presentation. 
Supervisor Brown requested the federal lobbyist also bring information 
forward on the current administration's immigration policies.
Page 11
Solano County

June 3, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ADJOURN:
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors adjourned at 11:03 
A.M. Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be June
10, 2025, at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street, Fairfield,
California.
________________________________
MITCH H. MASHBURN, Chair
Solano County Board of Supervisors
BILL EMLEN, Clerk
Solano County Board of Supervisors
By ______________________________
Alicia Draves, Chief Deputy Clerk

chunks.item_title: Adopt and present a resolution recognizing June 14, 2025, as the 250th
chunks.text:
Adopt and present a resolution recognizing June 14, 2025, as the 250th 
birthday of the United States Army (Supervisor Vasquez)
A - US Army 250th Birthday Resolution
Attachments:
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2025-135, recognizing June 14, 2025, as the 250th 
birthday of the United States Army. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. (see Resolution 
Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-135
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on 
matters not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of 
the Board. The following comments were received:
A) Bob Megary commented on the protests and urged the Board to adopt a
resolution affirming that Solano County does not require military assistance
in the event of a protest.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated an item came to the attention of staff 
after the posting of the agenda, necessitating immediate action on the part of 
the Board of Supervisors regarding possible consideration to authorize the 
County Administrator to send a letter to the City of Suisun City listing the 
County’s concerns regarding the City of Suisun City Council’s potential 
approval of a California Forever Reimbursement Agreement, Consultant 
Professional Services Agreements, and Administrative Amendments.
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated a 4/5 vote is required to add the 
urgency item to the agenda.
On motion of Supervisor James, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
found that an item came to the attention of staff after the posting to the 
agenda, necessitating immediate action, and approved the addition of an 
urgency item to discuss and consider sending a letter to the City of Suisun 
City Council regarding potential approval of agreements with the Flannery 
Group for the California Forever project. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor James, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for June 10, 
2025, as amended to include the urgency item. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Page 2
Solano County

June 10, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Supervisor Brown commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 9, inquiring 
why the County Administrator's authorization threshold was increased from 
$74,999 to $75,000.
Chief Information Officer Department of Technology-Registrar of Voters Tim 
Flanagan explained the $74,999 amount represents the limit for contract 
approval, while the $75,000 threshold pertains to granting consent to apply 
for grants exceeding $75,000.
Supervisor Williams commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 12 and 
requested information regarding the nature of transcranial magnetic 
stimulation treatments (TMS).
Director of Health and Social Services Emery Cowan explained that TMS is a 
voluntary, non-invasive treatment option for individuals with 
treatment-resistant depression. Ms. Cowan further explained that TMS is an 
evidence-based model that delivers magnetic pulses through the brain.
Chair Mashburn commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 14, and 
congratulated Cathy Bidou on her retirement from the Sheriff's Office.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on items 
listed on the Consent Calendar. There was no public comment.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board approved the following Consent Calendar items by a 5-0 vote:

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on the launch of the Solanocounty.gov redesigned
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on the launch of the Solanocounty.gov redesigned 
website
Principal Management Analyst Megan Richards introduced the item and 
provided an overview of the redesigned Solano County website. 
Information Technology Project Manager Monique Richards provided some 
background on Phase 1 and Phase 2 of the website redesign, which 
included data collection, data findings, legal requirements, development of 
new site content and design, site building and launching of the new website.
A short live demonstration was presented.
Supervisor Brown recommended including floor information in the location 
details to ensure visitors are informed of the specific floor they need to 
access in order to receive a particular service.
Chair Mashburn thanked staff for their hard work on the website redesign. 
Received
19

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation providing an update on projects utilizing Solano
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation providing an update on projects utilizing Solano 
County American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) Coronavirus State and Local 
Fiscal Recovery Funds (SLFRF)
A - ARPA Expenditure Update
B - Revolving Loan Fund Update
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Megan Richards introduced the item and 
provided an expenditure update on the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA). 
Ms. Richards stated 100% of the funds have been obligated and as of March 
31, 2025, 72.3% of the funds have been expended.
President and CEO of Solano Economic Development Corporation, Chris 
Rico provided an overview of the Revolving Loan Fund, highlighting that 
loans were distributed to a diverse range of businesses, including 
women-owned and minority-owned businesses.
A brief video was shown highlighting local businesses and the positive 
impact the funding has had on their operations.
Assistant to the City Manager, City of Vallejo, Natalie Peterson provided an 
update on two funded projects: the Vallejo Navigation Center and the 
Broadway Street Permanent Supportive Housing Project.
Page 7
Solano County

June 10, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
20

chunks.item_title: Ms. Peterson stated the Vallejo Navigation Center is scheduled to open by
chunks.text:
Ms. Peterson stated the Vallejo Navigation Center is scheduled to open by 
the end of June 2025, and the Broadway Street Permanent Supportive 
Housing Project has an anticipated occupancy date of July 2025.
Ms. Richards provided an update on the Housing Trust Fund and stated the 
waitlist for Solano County units opens June 10, 2025.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the Public Notice flyer, emphasizing that 
while the City of Vacaville administers the Solano County Housing Authority, 
the flyer should feature the County seal.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding expended funds 
and tracking of those funds, Ms. Richards stated that staff is closely 
monitoring the amounts. Ms. Richards further stated that as projects 
conclude, any unused funds may be returned to the County and 
subsequently presented to the Board for appropriate reallocation.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the vaccination 
policy for pets at the Vallejo Navigation Center, Ms. Peterson stated that 
Animal Care Services visits the homeless encampments regularly and has 
vaccinated many of the animals at the encampments. Ms. Peterson 
expressed hope that Humane Society and the Sheriff’s Department will 
assist with vaccinating animals whose vaccination status is unknown.
In response to a question from Supervisor James regarding eligibility 
requirements and drug use, Ms. Peterson stated that the use of drugs and 
alcohol is not permitted on-site at the Vallejo Navigation Center. Ms. 
Peterson further stated that prior convictions do not disqualify individuals 
from accessing services at the Center. However, for the Broadway facility, 
Ms. Peterson noted that while the Housing First model with a harm-reduction 
approach is prioritized, HUD regulations take precedence and may impose 
certain limitations due to funding requirements.
Ms. Peterson extended an invitation to the Board to tour the facilities.
Received
Receive a verbal update from Paragon Government Relations, the County’s 
federal 
Legislative 
Advocates 
and 
Karen 
Lange, 
the 
County’s 
State 
Legislative Advocate on legislative matters of interest to the County
Assistant County Administrator Debbie Vaughn introduced the item. 
Federal Legislative Advocate Joe Krahn provided an update on current 
legislation of interest to the County.
Federal Legislative Advocates Tom Joseph and Hasan Sarsour provided an overview 
of the federal budget and reconciliation process.
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding the Delta, 
specifically whether there has been any further discussion about transferring 
permitting review authority from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to the 
Page 8
Solano County

June 10, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Mr. Krahn stated that active 
discussions are ongoing; however, there is currently no indication as to 
whether the EPA intends to exercise its veto authority.
Chair Mashburn commented on the proposed Medicare and Medi-Cal 
reductions, noting that while such cuts are often presented as federal 
savings, the financial burden is effectively shifted to counties, which are then 
responsible for covering the associated costs.
In response to a follow-up question from Chair Mashburn regarding a 
potential proposal for Travis Air Force Base (TAFB) to serve as a holding 
facility for immigration detainees, Mr. Krahn stated that the possibility 
remains under consideration and affirmed that he will keep the Board 
informed as new information becomes available.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the vote on the 
debt ceiling and safety cuts and their potential impact on individuals pursuing 
higher education, Mr. Joseph indicated that the U.S. Treasury may address 
the debt ceiling vote this summer; however, no definitive date has been set. 
Concerning the education-related implications, Mr. Joseph noted that there is 
currently no clear guidance or definitive information on the specific education 
requirements; however, at the County level, caseworkers may be faced with 
increased workload demands due to the need to begin documenting service 
hours.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding potential 
funding cuts to rental assistance for low-income housing and homelessness 
programs, Mr. Joseph stated that the President’s proposed budget for the 
upcoming fiscal year includes significant reductions in funding for housing 
and homelessness initiatives. Mr. Joseph further stated the proposal 
includes a plan to consolidate a broad range of programs-such as public 
housing vouchers and homelessness services-into a single block grant.
State Legislative Advocate Karen Lange provided an update on current 
legislation of interest to the County.
Supervisor Vasquez commented that the state has shown leniency in holding 
private cemeteries accountable and emphasized that the responsibility 
should lie with the cemetery owners.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding program cuts 
and free meals for students, Ms. Lange stated the funding cuts to 
universities and California State universities were rejected by the legislature. 
Chair Mashburn expressed gratitude to the federal and state legislative 
advocates, as well as to the city and county staff, for their dedicated efforts 
and hard work.
Received

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on the launch of PulsePoint, a public safety alert
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on the launch of PulsePoint, a public safety alert 
system 
for 
CPR-trained 
individuals 
available 
to 
respond 
to 
nearby 
emergencies
Emergency Services Manager Robyn Rains introduced the item and 
provided background on PulsePoint, a system comprised of two mobile 
applications-PulsePoint Respond and PulsePoint AED, that are integrated 
with a Public Safety Answering Point (PSAP), or 911 dispatch center, and 
are designed to alert CPR/AED-trained individuals to nearby incidents of 
cardiac arrest.
Emergency Medical Services Coordinator Scott Wagness stated the goals of 
PulsePoint are to reduce cardiac deaths by decreasing collapse to CPR and 
collapse to defibrillation times and to enhance public situational awareness 
of emergency incidents. 
Mr. Wagness provided an overview of the functionality of the PulsePoint 
system and the benefits of receiving the notifications in emergency 
situations. 
Ms. Rains explained that Solano County has eight Public Safety Answering 
Points (PSAPs), but currently, only the Solano County Emergency 
Communication Center (ECC) has implemented PulsePoint. Ms. Rains 
further explained only agencies dispatched by the ECC receive PulsePoint 
notifications and stated that for PulsePoint to be deployed countywide, each 
PSAP would need to establish its own contract with PulsePoint and integrate 
the system with its respective Computer-Aided Dispatch (CAD) provider.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need for centralized dispatch. 
A brief explanation was provided on how to access PulsePoint using both 
desktop computers and mobile devices.
Received
22

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on the Sheriff Office’s Behavioral Health Unit at the
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on the Sheriff Office’s Behavioral Health Unit at the 
Justice 
Center 
Detention 
Facility; 
and 
Consider 
adopting 
a 
resolution 
amending the List of Numbers and Classifications of Positions to add 2.0 
FTE Custody Sergeants and delete 3.0 FTE Correctional Officers in the 
Custody Division of the Sheriff’s Office (4/5 vote required)
A - Position Resolution
Attachments:
Undersheriff Brad DeWall introduced the item and provided background on 
the Behavioral Health Unit (BHU), describing it as step-up/step-down 
housing for incarcerated individuals with mental health diagnoses or 
behavioral challenges that affect their ability to function in the general 
population. Undersheriff DeWall further stated the BHU will offer specialized 
care, including increased monitoring, therapeutic interventions, and 
programming to support mental health management and adjustment to the 
jail environment. 
Page 10
Solano County

June 10, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Captain Bill Hornbrook commented on the prevalence of mental illness in the 
jail population, noting that as of May 2025, around 55% of the Solano County 
jail population has been identified as having mental health conditions, and 
emphasized that some individuals require more attention than a standard 
housing unit can accommodate. Mr. Hornbrook highlighted the positive 
impacts the BHU will have on the inmates and staff.
Custody Lieutenant Daniel Castillo presented an overview of the Behavioral 
Health Unit (BHU) configuration within the Justice Center Detention Facility 
and detailed the associated staffing changes and requirements.
Sheriff Criminal Justice Program Services Manage Renee Smith provided an 
overview on the BHU incentive programs and inmate program requirements. 
Administrative Services Manager Lisa Donahue provided an overview of the 
financial impacts on facility improvements, staffing and ongoing BHU 
support. 
Supervisor Vasquez, Chair Mashburn and Supervisor Williams thanked staff 
for the presentation and their dedicated efforts and hard work.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2025-141, amending the List of Numbers and 
Classifications of Positions to add 2.0 FTE Custody Sergeants and delete 3.0 
FTE Correctional Officers in the Custody Division of the Sheriff’s Office. So 
ordered by a 5-0 vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-141
URGENCY ITEM ADDED
County Administrator:

23
Consider authorizing the County Administrator to send a letter to the City of 
Suisun City listing the County’s concerns regarding the City of Suisun City 
Council’s potential approval of a California Forever Reimbursement 
Agreement, 
Consultant 
Professional 
Services 
Agreements, 
and 
Administrative Amendments
County Administrator Bill Emlen provided background on the California 
Forever initiative and prior discussions regarding potential annexation in 
Suisun City and Rio Vista. Mr. Emlen stated the Suisun City Council is 
scheduled to consider an item on its June 10, 2025, agenda involving a 
series of reimbursement agreements with various consultants to initiate the 
annexation process and amend the city’s sphere of influence to incorporate 
the California Forever proposal. Mr. Emlen further explained the proposal 
involves expanding Suisun City by approximately 22,873 acres, which would 
lead to significant urban development in eastern Solano County. Mr. Emlen 
reminded the Board that under the current General Plan, these areas are 
designated for agricultural use and habitat preservation.
Page 11
Solano County

June 10, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Mr. Emlen requested the Board authorize staff to send a letter to the Suisun 
City Council prior to the city council meeting expressing the County’s position 
and concerns. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the discussion 
parameters considering the item was added as an urgency item, County 
Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the Brown Act does allow for discussion 
since it is an urgency item; however, it is recommended that the discussion 
stay within the parameters of previous board direction.
Supervisor Brown requested the discussion held at the Solano County 
City-County Coordinating Council (4Cs) be included in the letter.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams on whether the County’s 
letter will be made available to the Suisun City residents, Mr. Emlen stated 
the decision to share the letter is up to the discretion of the Suisun City 
Council.
Supervisor Cassandra James requested the item be brought back after the 
Suisun City Council meeting for further discussion. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Suisun City Mayor Alma Hernandez spoke in support of the
reimbursement agreements between Suisun City and California
Forever.
B) Suisun City Manager Bret Prebula spoke in support of the potential
annexation and expansion of Suisun City.
C) Michael Fortney of California Forever requested the Board allow
California Forever Attorney Jennifer Hernandez to make a public
comment via call-in.
D) Lauren Newhouse, outside counsel for Suisun City, expressed
opposition to the Board's decision to add this discussion as an
urgency item stating it is a violation of the Brown Act.
E) California Forever Attorney Jennifer Hernandez commented in
support of the potential annexation and expansion of Suisun City.
F) Suisun City Vice Mayor Jenalee Dawson commented in support of
the potential annexation and expansion of Suisun City.
G) Ruth Forney requested the Board refrain from sending a letter to the
Suisun City Council.
Ms. Curry explained that because the Suisun City Council is set to take 
action on the item at tonight’s meeting, it was necessary to include the 
matter on the agenda as an urgency item, requiring a four-fifths vote for 
Page 12
Solano County

June 10, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
approval. Ms. Curry stated that the County is requesting the Suisun City 
Council to pause its actions to allow for additional discussions, in alignment 
with the Board’s previously stated direction, and further stated the item being 
presented to the Suisun City Council is not consistent with the guidance 
provided by the Board.
In response to Supervisor James’ request for clarification regarding the 
contents of the letter, Mr. Emlen indicated that it will emphasize the 
consistency with the General Plan and incorporate discussions from previous 
4Cs meetings.
On motion of Supervisor Brown, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the Board 
authorized the County Administrator to send a letter to the City of Suisun City 
listing the County’s concerns regarding the City of Suisun City Council’s 
potential approval of a California Forever Reimbursement Agreement, 
Consultant Professional Services Agreements, and Administrative 
Amendments So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional items from the public.

on meetings. The following comments were received:
A. Chair Mashburn invited all attendees to visit the Solano County Fair
taking place in Vallejo this weekend.

F - Link to the FY2025/26 Recommended Budget
G - Budget Notice
Attachments:
County Administrator Bill Emlen introduced the item and provided an overview of 
factors that affected the creation of the FY2025/26 Recommended Budget. 
Page 2
Solano County

June 23, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Budget 
Officer 
Emily 
Combs 
provided 
an 
overview 
of 
the 
FY2025/26 
Recommended Budget.
Supervisor Williams commented on Budget Unit 5800 - Veterans Services noting 
she has concerns over the amount of staffing vs. the actual population of 
veterans and their families in Solano County. Supervisor Williams inquired why 
comparisons are being made with counties that have significantly smaller 
veterans populations. Supervisor Williams commented on the need for more 
certified staff to process service requests for the veterans population and their 
families and made a recommendation to create a Deputy Director - Veterans 
Services position to ensure if the Director is not present, all services are still able 
to be processed. 
In response to Supervisor Williams comments regarding certified staff, Assistant 
County Administrator Ian Goldberg stated in addition to the Director of Veterans 
Services, there are two staff members who are currently certified; one employee 
within the Veterans Services Department at the County Administration Center 
who is currently out on leave and one certified employee that is housed at Travis 
AFB. Mr. Goldberg noted there has been significant turnover within Veterans 
Services, and the County Administrator’s Office (CAO) has continued to work to 
fill those positions. Mr. Goldberg further stated staff is working to train and obtain 
certification for current staff and with the addition of two more positions previously 
approved by the Board, staffing within the department is at the highest it has ever 
been. Mr. Goldberg stated the CAO has decided the best course of action at this 
time is to evaluate overall operations within the department to see where 
improvements can be made, noting revenues within the department are currently 
on the decline. 
Mr. Emlen stated there have been issues within the department and the CAO has 
been working with the Director to rectify those issues. Mr. Emlen further stated, 
given that the department is now fully staffed, the CAO would like time to evaluate 
staff further and to continue to work with the department to ensure all current staff 
have received their certifications. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the previous service levels of the department, 
noting under the previous director, staff retention and certifications were not an 
issue. Chair Mashburn further stated the department previously had been able to 
process more service applications than any other Veterans Services in the entire 
State. Chair Mashburn further stated a change in departmental leadership led to 
the current issues within the department and recommended CAO review both 
staff training and management within Veterans Services.
Supervisor Williams restated her concern regarding Solano County veterans not 
receiving needed services, noting she wants to ensure the department is 
receiving the support it needs. 
Supervisor Vasquez inquired if Supervisor Williams is requesting an additional 
position or the creation of a position to be filled by current staff. 
Page 3
Solano County

June 23, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Williams stated she is recommending once there is a review of 
current staffing and certifications staff look at potentially creating a new Deputy 
Director position to be filled potentially by a current staff member.
Supervisor 
Vasquez 
recommended 
CAO 
complete 
both 
a 
tabletop 
and 
management audit, as well as potentially looking at the possibility of merging the 
department with a larger department that provides similar services such as 
Health and Social Services. 
Chair Mashburn noted there will be no changes to Veterans Services 
departmental budget at this time. 
Supervisor Brown recommended a tabletop and management audit for the 
Solano Economic Development Corporation (EDC), noting she has concerns 
regarding if the County is receiving enough benefits from the money that is being 
allocated to the Solano EDC. Supervisor Brown further stated she is not currently 
recommending changes to the budget; however, she is requesting a review of the 
cost to benefit ratio of services being provided to Solano County.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A)
Director of Veterans Services Alfred Sims commented on the need for
additional management staff within the department.
In

This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent Calendar.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation from the Public Defender on the selection of Jennifer
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation from the Public Defender on the selection of Jennifer 
Artz as the July 2025 “Employee of the Month” for the County Administration 
Center Parking Program
Received
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on 
matters not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of 
the Board. The following comments were received:
A) Joseph Johnson commented on the reopening of the Continentals of
Omega Girls and Boys Club of Vallejo on January 1, 2026.
Page 2
Solano County

June 24, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of 
Supervisors' agenda for June 24. 2025.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for June 24, 
2025, as submitted. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on items 
listed on the Consent Calendar. The following comments were received:
A) Alexis Koefoed commented in support of Consent Calendar Item No. 8.
B)
Tony Esposo commented on Consent Calendar Item No 18, voicing
concerns over the removal of his company from the list of available
contractors for the Master Services Agreements.
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated Consent Calendar Item No. 18 is the 
Master Services Agreements, which have a duration of 3 years and is for 
projects that require larger firms, noting Mr. Esposo’s firm is a one-man 
operation. Ms. Curry further stated Mr. Esposo is not precluded from 
submitting other bids for other opportunities to work for Solano County. His 
removal from the list is only in terms of the Master Services Agreements.
Chair Mashburn directed staff to set aside time to brief the Board regarding 
this situation, even if it is a closed session. 
Supervisor 
James 
commented 
on 
Consent 
Calendar 
Item 
No. 
12, 
to 
acknowledge Ms. Smith’s hard work during her time at Solano County as the 
Volunteer Coordinator. 
Supervisor Brown commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 27, noting the 
Behavioral Health Advisory Board will be bringing the Board a presentation on 
Proposition 1 funding. 
Supervisor Williams commented on Consent Calendar No. 38, requesting 
more information on the past work completed and on the proposed project.
In response to Supervisor Williams' comments, Planning Program Manager 
Allan Calder provided an overview of past actions related to this project and 
plans for a future low impact agritourism program going forward. 
Supervisor Williams requested that staff provide her with the scope of work 
for the project. 
Page 3
Solano County

June 24, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Vasquez noted that this project was called out in the 2008 General 
Plan, and in 2021, as part of the visioning process, a survey was completed. 
Supervisor Vasquez stated he would provide Supervisor Williams with a copy 
of the survey.
Chair Mashburn commented on Consent Calendar Item No. 33, recognizing 
Collections Officer Dorcas Terrado on her retirement. 
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Brown, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the Board 
approved the following Consent Calendar items by 5-0 vote:

chunks.item_title: Receive a report on the Solano County
chunks.text:
Receive a report on the Solano County 
2024 Index of Economic and 
Community Progress
A - 2024 Index of Economic and Community Progress
B - 2024 Index Presentation Slides
Attachments:
Principal Management Analyst Matthew Davis introduced the item.
Dr. Robert Eyler provided an overview of the Solano County 2024 Index of 
Economic and Community Progress.
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the future of agricultural technology and 
how Solano County can take advantage of assets such as UC Davis. 
In response to concerns raised by Supervisor Brown regarding a potential 
economic downturn in addition to federal cuts in spending on SNAP and 
Medi-Cal, Dr. Eyler stated the County needs to engage in more economic 
development, however, there are going to be budget issues facing all 
municipalities in the state due to cost of living increases. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the potential 
shortfalls of planning for warehousing and manufacturing to be an economic 
driver when much of the work is now automated, Mr. Eyler stated the County 
is well situated for these types of industries because of its location between 
the Bay Area and Sacramento, however, it will have to balance bringing in 
industry like warehouses where there might be a large footprint but not a lot of 
local jobs, and working to bring in other industries that might create more 
local jobs.
In response to a question from Supervisor James regarding potential social 
inequities in the County, Dr. Eyler stated the data is within the larger 
document, noting he didn’t call out socioeconomic issues in his presentation 
because his focus was on the economic side. Dr. Eyler further stated it is 
important to coordinate economic development and workforce development 
activities together, which will create a local workforce trained in the industries 
you are attempting to bring in, which will then help to lift up specific 
communities. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment. 
Received
48

chunks.text:
Consider 
accepting 
a 
Federal 
Emergency 
Management 
Agency 
Hazard

Justice Campus Asset Protection Project; Delegate authority to the County 
Administrator or designee to execute any agreements, amendments, or other 
documents 
necessary 
to

the 
grant 
requirements; 
Approve

Page 15
Solano County

June 24, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Director 
to 
solicit 
bids, 
award 
construction 
and 
other 
project-related 
contracts, including any amendments, with County Counsel concurrence, to 
support project delivery within the grant period of performance and approved 
project budget; and Approve an exception to the Board's existing policy on 
Project Labor Agreements for this Project due to the period of performance
A - HMGP Approval Letter
B - Budget Summary
Attachments:
Director of General Services Megan Greve introduced the item and provided a 
history of the recommended project. 
Capital Projects Division Manager Mark Hummel provided an overview of the 
current recommended project.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the potential use 
of apprentice workers, Mr. Hummel stated the contracting will be done in 
accordance with the Department of Industrial Relations requirements which 
has specific apprenticeship programs that are approved for specific types of 
job classifications.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board: 
1) accepted a Federal Emergency Management Agency Hazard Mitigation
Grant Program award of $19,844,231 to augment funding for the Justice
Campus Asset Protection Project; 2) delegated authority to the County
Administrator or designee to execute any agreements, amendments, or other
documents necessary to implement the grant requirements; 3) approved
subsequent Appropriation Transfer Requests to recognize the unanticipated
revenues for the project (4/5 vote required); 4) authorized the General Services
Director to solicit bids, award construction and other project-related contracts,
including any amendments, with County Counsel concurrence, to support
project delivery within the grant period of performance and approved project
budget; and 5) approved an exception to the Board's existing policy on Project
Labor Agreements for this Project due to the period of performance. So
ordered by a 5-0 vote.
