chunks.item_title: Hold a meeting of the Montezuma, Suisun and Vacaville Fire Protection
chunks.text:
Hold a meeting of the Montezuma, Suisun and Vacaville Fire Protection 
Districts; Consider approving a Supplemental Policy Document for the three 
districts; Consider delegating the County Administrator authority to appoint an 
Interim 
Chief; 
Consider 
delegating 
the 
County 
Administrator 
authority 
to 
approve emergency purchases up to $250,000 and to provide concurrence 
Page 17
Solano County

June 24, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
on personnel decisions; Consider adopting a resolution establishing a 14-day 
work period; Consider initiating an Audit process for the three Districts for 
financial 
statements 
from 
FY2023/24 and 
FY2024/25 and 
FY2021/22 and 
FY2022/23 for the Vacaville Fire Protection District
A - Supplemental Policies
B - Resolution MFPD
C - Resolution SFPD
D - Resolution VFPD
Attachments:
Senior Management Analyst Nancy Nelson introduced the item and the 
recommended action. 
Supervisor Vasquez inquired if the County Administrator’s title should be 
changed to the District Administrator, given the fact that the Board is sitting as 
the Board of Directors of the Fire Districts and not as the Board of 
Supervisors.
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the Board would have to take action 
to appoint the County Administrator as the District Administrator. 
Montezuma Fire Protection District Chief Michael O’Connor provided an 
overview of the request for the Board to adopt a resolution to establish a 
14-day work period.
Suisun Fire Protection District Chief Alfred Abruzzini provided an overview of 
the annual audit process for the three districts. 
Chief O’Connor provided an overview of the services provided by the 
Montezuma Fire Protection District for 2025.
Chief Abruzzini provided an overview of the services provided by the Suisun 
Fire Protection District for 2025.
Vacaville Fire Protection District Interim/Deputy Chief Dave Kuntz provided an 
overview of the services provided by the Vacaville Fire Protection District for 
2025.
Ms. Nelson provided an overview of the steps that are being taken on the 
consolidation 
of 
the 
districts. 
Ms. 
Nelson 
noted 
there 
is 
a 
correction 
necessary to the staff report regarding the need for the Vacaville Fire 
Protection District to complete an audit for FY2021/22, noting, that they had 
already completed an audit for that year. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the graduating 
class from Solano Community College being so small, Chief Kuntz stated 
that the class was actual employees, noting the volunteers' graduation was 
much larger and took place in Winters.
Page 18
Solano County

June 24, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Williams asked about the process for appointing an interim chief, 
noting the Board did not receive any information on the applicants for the 
Board to make a decision.
Ms. Nelson stated the recommendation is for the County Administrator to 
appoint the interim chief in the same manner that he would appoint a 
department head.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Mark Van Pelt commented on concerns over the potential closure of the
Vine Street Fire Station as a result of the consolidation.
Supervisor Vasquez stated there are no plans at this time to close the Vine 
Street Fire Station. 
B) Liann Stubblefield commented on the potential appointment of an interim
fire chief by the County Administrator, inquired if the Board will appoint a
commission to oversee the consolidated fire protection districts, and stated
concerns over perceived Brown Act violations.
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the Board has not appointed a 
commission to oversee the districts, but the Board does have the option to do 
so if they wish. Ms. Curry further stated it would be appropriate for the Board 
to appoint the County Administrator as District Administrator. Ms. Curry 
further stated with regard to concerns voiced over the perceived Brown Act 
violations, the Board is required to post the agenda at the location they meet, 
noting the Board has taken steps to be the official legislative body of the three 
fire protection districts and the agenda was posted both at the physical 
location where the Board meets as well as online. Ms. Curry further stated the 
Brown Act only requires the County to provide sufficient information in the title 
to provide adequate notice of what the Board will be discussing. Mr. Curry 
noted that there is no requirement in the Brown Act for the Board to provide 
the PowerPoint ahead of the meeting, and the title that was provided was 
more than sufficient for anybody who was interested in attending to hear this 
item.
C) Rose Loveall commented on concerns over potentially shuttering rural fire
stations during the non-fire season, noting there is no season for medical
emergencies.
Supervisor Williams stated she would prefer the Board complete interviews 
for the position of the Interim Chief instead of having the County Administrator 
make the appointment.
Chair Mashburn commented on the appointment process, noting that when 
the County Administrator appoints a department head, he puts together a 
panel of individuals who are experts in that field to complete the interviews 
and then he takes their recommendation and makes the appointment. Chair 
Page 19
Solano County

June 24, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Mashburn further stated he is not comfortable with the Board making the 
appointment as they do not have the expertise necessary to choose a chief 
not knowing enough about fire at the professional level. 
Supervisor Williams commented that when the Board hired the Director of 
Health and Social Services the Board did have a panel of experts but it also 
had the opportunity to interview the applicants and she would prefer that this 
appointment follow that process.
Chair Mashburn stated the Board could direct the County Admini

chunks.item_title: Receive an update on the Sheriff Office’s ability to provide temporary law
chunks.text:
Receive an update on the Sheriff Office’s ability to provide temporary law 
enforcement assistance to the City of Vallejo; and Provide direction on a 
proposed contract for services
A - Term Sheet
B - Deputy Sheriffs Association Letter
C - Draft Contract Vallejo Law Enforcement Services
Attachments:
Sheriff-Coroner 
Tom 
Ferrara 
introduced 
the 
item 
and 
provided 
a 
brief 
overview of the contract negotiation timeline, as well as an update on the 
County's current standing in this process. Sheriff Ferrara noted that all 
milestones had been completed with the exception of a meet and confer and 
approval by the Deputy Sheriff’s Association. Sheriff Ferrara stated even 
though they are not going to meet the July 1, 2025, deadline, the Board could 
direct staff to continue to meet and confer to potentially resolve the identified 
issues. Sheriff Ferrara further stated in addition, there are concerns over a 
directive from Human Resources that will require the Sheriff’s office to let go 
of 8 retired annuitants, meaning it will now be necessary to hire 25 individuals 
to fulfill the contract with the courts and the City of Vallejo. Sheriff Ferrara 
further stated that should the Board decide to continue this item he will need 
them to direct staff to cut much of the bureaucratic red tape to get all items in 
place in time for this contract to go into effect in January 1, 2026.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A)
Dr. Tonia Lediju commented in support of the Vallejo temporary law
enforcement assistance contract.
B) Vallejo City Manager Andrew Murray commented in support of the Vallejo
temporary law enforcement assistance contract.
C)
Patricia Hunter commented in support of the Vallejo temporary law
enforcement assistance contract.
D) Dr. Ramona Bishop commented in support of the Vallejo temporary law
enforcement assistance contract.
E) Vallejo City Council Member J.R. Matulac commented in support of the
Vallejo temporary law enforcement assistance contract.
F) Deputy Chief of Police Bob Knight commented in support of the Vallejo
temporary law enforcement assistance contract.
G)
Marissa Serafino commented in support of the Vallejo temporary law
enforcement assistance contract.
H)
José Carrizales commented in support of the Vallejo temporary law
enforcement assistance contract.
Page 21
Solano County

June 24, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
I)
Vice President of the Deputy Sheriff’s Association (DSA) Todd OConner
commented 
in 
opposition 
of 
the 
Vallejo 
temporary 
law 
enforcement
assistance contract as it is written and in support of continuing to meet and
confer in order to potentially resolve current issues.
J) Vallejo City Council Member Alexander Matias commented in support of
the Vallejo temporary law enforcement assistance contract.
K)
Vallejo City Mayor Andrea Sorce commented in support of the Vallejo
temporary law enforcement assistance contract.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if the DSA is 
willing to continue to meet and confer, Mr. OConner stated the DSA is willing 
to continue negotiations until the July 22, 2025, Board Meeting.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the requirement 
to release the eight retired annuitant deputies, Director of Human Resources 
Niger Edwards stated after an audit from CalPERS, the County was notified 
that it has multiple retirees that have gone beyond the 3-year term allowed for 
retired annuitants to work. Ms. Edwards further stated that should the County 
not terminate those retired annuitants, it will impact their retirement. Ms. 
Edwards further stated that CalPERS would require them to come out of 
retirement and could potentially require them to pay back all retirement funds 
they have received, not just from when they returned to working, but since 
their retirement. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams on if the legislation 
passed by Senator Dodd would cover those retired annuitants that are being 
let go, Ms. Edwards stated she believes that the extension is related strictly to 
when providing services to the City of Vallejo.
Chair Mashburn stated the legislation has not kicked in because the County 
does not have a contract with the City of Vallejo. Chair Mashburn further 
stated keeping the retired annuitants on could potentially cost those retirees 
hundreds of thousands of dollars they received in retirement.
A discussion period was held regarding the issues surrounding the use of 
CalPERS retired annuitants and the inability to fulfill the contract if the Sheriff 
is required to hire 8 additional deputies.
Chair Mashburn directed staff to clarify the legality of the continued use of the 
retired annuitants that have surpassed the 3-year deadline.
Assistant County Counsel Carrie Blacklock stated the Board is looking at two 
different issues, noting there is the legislation that addresses how many 
hours a year a retired annuitant can work. Ms. Blacklock further stated that's 
what the County has as an exception for under the Senator Dodd-sponsored 
legislation, which Solano County hasn’t triggered yet. Ms. Blacklock further 
stated there is also a limitation on the number of years a retired annuitant can 
work, and that is what CalPERS is telling the County it has been exceeding. 
Page 22
Solano County

June 24, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Ms. Blacklock further stated, the max hours exemption doesn't help the 
County address the current issue with the bailiffs, who have worked as retired 
annuitants for so many years. Ms. Blacklock further stated that the County 
can attempt to fight this out with CalPERS; however, it puts those retired 
annuitants at risk. 
A lengthy discussion period was held regarding the potential ramifications of 
the CalPERS issue combined with trying to hire enough staff for the City of 
Vallejo law enforcement assistance contra

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation providing further background on the City of Suisun
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation providing further background on the City of Suisun 
City’s recent action to enter into a Reimbursement Agreement with California 
Forever LP related to the proposed annexation of approximately 22,873 acres 
of unincorporated land into the City of Suisun City including a large part of 
what is now being referred to as the Suisun Expansion Specific Plan; Affirm 
the Board’s previous direction regarding the letter to the City of Suisun City 
requesting action on the Reimbursement Agreement and the plan moving 
forward be deferred; Establish the County’s position and direct staff to 
proceed accordingly that any expansion plans by the City should be brought 
forward through the County’s General Plan Update process based on the 
scale and scope of the plan referenced in the Reimbursement Agreement 
and the amount of unincorporated area under consideration
A - Summary of Reimbursement Agreement
B - County Letter to City of Suisun City
C - Reimbursement Agreement Map
D - Suisun Area General Plan Map
E - Suisun Area Zoning Map
F - Williamson Act Parcels Map
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item and 
provided background information on previous actions taken by staff and the 
Board on the East Solano Plan and the City of Suisun Reimbursement 
Agreement. 
Mr. 
Bezek 
provided 
a 
summary 
of 
the 
City 
of 
Suisun 
Reimbursement Agreement and East Solano annexation proposal.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A)
Denise Lyons commented in opposition to the proposal of the City of
Suisun for the annexation.
B) City of Suisun City Manager Bret Prebula commented on the timeline of
Page 26
Solano County

June 24, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
the plan, noting the City of Suisun has tried to be as transparent as possible
in this process and stated they desire to work with the County in this process.
C)
City of Suisun Mayor Alma Hernandez commented on the discussions
that took place at the City County Coordinating Council (4Cs), noting after
listening to the recording, there was no request for the cities not to move
forward on potential plans for annexations nor did any of the mayors agree to
not move forward with any plans. Mayor Hernandez further stated it is the
hope of the City of Suisun to collaborate with the County on Suisun’s plans,
noting they are simply in the planning stages of studying the land and are not
committed to annexing all 22,000 acres.
D)
Bob Berman commented in opposition to the proposal of the City of
Suisun for the annexation and noted concerns over the possibility that the
City of Suisun used a sole source provider for the completion of the EIR who
previously worked for California Forever.
E) Jim DeKloe commented in opposition to the proposal of the City of Suisun
for the annexation.
F) Duane Kromm commented in opposition to the proposal of the City of
Suisun for the annexation.
G) City of Suisun Vice Mayor Jenalee Dawson commented on the time frame
for the project, noting full build-out will not be for 50 to 70 years.
H) James Berg commented in opposition to the proposal of the City of Suisun
for the annexation.
I) Michelle Chavez commented on the proposed City of Suisun annexation.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding the staff 
recommendation, Mr. Emlen stated the County’s current position is that 
expansion of this magnitude should be handled through the County’s General 
Plan process.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding if Mr. Prebula 
was denied a meeting with the CAO to discuss this project, Mr. Emlen stated 
early in the process he met with both Mr. Prebula and the City Manager for 
Rio Vista at which time he told them he felt this should be a County driven 
process and that the annexation is inconsistent with the County’s current 
General Plan. Mr. Emlen further stated at that point in time, before having any 
further conversations, he felt it was necessary to receive direction from the 
Board. 
Supervisor Williams voiced concerns that the City of Suisun is getting ahead 
of the County’s jurisdiction, noting she feels the City of Suisun should be 
working with the County as part of the upcoming General Plan process and 
she doesn’t want to take away the ability of the citizens to vote on this project. 
Supervisor Williams stated she would like to see more cooperation between 
the two jurisdictions. Supervisor Williams further stated there is a necessity 
Page 27
Solano County

June 24, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
for the County to be willing to help the City of Suisun
In response to Supervisor Williams’ comments, Mr. Bezek stated that, as it is 
currently written, the citizens will not be voting on this item, noting that should 
the annexation be approved, the City of Suisun could choose to no longer 
conform to the Airport Land Use Commission (ALUC) rules.
Ms. Curry stated that if the annexation is approved, even if the ALUC makes a 
determination that the project is inconsistent with the Travis Airport Land Use 
Compatibility Plan as well as the Rio Vista Airport Land Use Compatibility 
Plan, the City of Suisun can override the determination. Ms. Curry further 
stated this happened previously with the Walmart project that was built in the 
City of Suisun, noting that the ALUC made a determination that the project 
was inconsistent with the Travis Airport Land Use Compatibility Plan and the 
Suisun City Council did an override stating that regardless of the ALUC’s 
determination, the Walmart project was more important to the City of Suisun 
than the concerns of the ALUC and its impacts on Travis AFB. Ms. Curry 
further noted as a result of this, the land use compatibility plan for Travis AFB 
had to be amended to accommodate the fact that there was an inconsistent 
use near the end of the runway. Ms. Curry further stated the big picture is one 
city

1)

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation by staff from the California Department of Water
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation by staff from the California Department of Water 
Resources and the Central Valley Flood Protection Board on the status and 
development of the Yolo Bypass Cache Slough Master Plan 
A - Comment Letter
B - Background
Attachments:
Water and Natural Resources Program Manager Misty Kaltreider introduced 
the item. 
California Department of Water Resources (DWR) Manager Steve Rothert 
provided an overview of the Yolo Bypass Cache Slough Master Plan.
Central Valley Flood Protection Board Program Manager Kristyne Van Skike 
provided an overview of the Yolo Bypass Cache Slough Partnership.
In response to questions from Supervisor Brown regarding the potential 
impacts for Solano County of the Yolo Bypass Cache Sough Master Plan and 
Partnership, Chair Mashburn stated the primary intent of this project is to 
provide flood relief. Chair Mashburn further stated the plans proposed 
outcome will be restorative to local habitat in the area. Chair Mashburn further 
stated the impacts to Solano County are the possibility there will be a loss of 
agricultural land; however, positive impacts may include an improvement in 
local habitat and the potential for a new recreational area. 
Chair Mashburn commented on issues Solano County has faced with the 
State imposing projects on Solano County that do not benefit the residents. 
Page 7
Solano County

July 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Chair Mashburn further stated as DWR begins to create a strategic plan for 
this project, it is imperative that the residents have a say in the process and 
that the County realizes some benefits for being the funnel for the flood 
waters from northern California. Chair Mashburn further stated at the project 
level there must be assurances that there is flood protection for the Solano 
County region.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding what potential 
flood mitigation tools will be put in place to protect Solano County, Mr. Rothert 
provided an overview of a potential project, that if approved, will improve 
certain levees to protect the Rio Vista area.
Received
21

In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the City of

In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding if the $2.50 
annual increase is enough to cover costs, Mr. Lee stated the funding goes

chunks.item_title: Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider adopting resolutions confirming
chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider adopting resolutions confirming 
reports of delinquent garbage accounts for mandatory garbage collection, 
disposal, and recycling services in the unincorporated areas of the County 
provided by Recology Vacaville Solano, Recology Vallejo, Rio Vista Sanitation 
Service DBA Mt. Diablo Resource Recovery, and Solano Garbage Company 
DBA Republic Services; Approve a $62 administrative charge per parcel for 
County departments to recover costs; Direct the Clerk of the Board to file a 
certified copy of the resolutions with the Recorder Division for recordation 
creating liens against the parcels; Authorize the Auditor-Controller to impose 
the delinquent fees and administrative charges as special assessments on 
the FY2025/26 property tax roll; and Authorize the Department of Resource 
Management to record a Release of Lien when delinquent accounts are paid
A - Recology Vacaville Solano Resolution
B - Rio Vista Sanitation Service (Mt. Diablo Resource Recovery) Resolution
C - Solano Garbage Company (Republic Services) Resolution
D - Recology Vallejo Resolution
E - 2025 Report of Delinquent Solid Waste Accounts
F - Map of Solid Waste Service Areas A-E
G - Notice of Public Hearing
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Principal Planner Narcisa Untal provided a brief overview of the process for 
identifying delinquent accounts and stated due to efforts of the garbage 
companies, many individuals were removed from the list prior to today's 
meeting. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding if there is a 
process to confirm if the individual who owns the property is alive and aware 
of the debt, Ms. Untal stated each garbage agency was asked to notify every 
property owner and she will confirm with them that they completed this 
process. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding if there is a limit 
to what residents will be charged, Ms. Untal stated Solano County requires 
residents to have garbage services, therefore they will continue to be billed. 
Mr. Bezek stated unpaid accounts will continue to have liens placed on their 
properties which will restrict the owner from being able to refinance their 
home or sell their property.
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments 
from the public 
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board: 
1) adopted Resolution No. 2025-166 confirming delinquent accounts for solid
waste services provided in unincorporated Solano County Service Area “A” by
Recology Vacaville Solano and authorizing the processing of real property
liens in accordance with Government Code section 25831; 2) adopted
Resolution No. 2025-167 confirming delinquent accounts for solid waste
services provided in unincorporated solano County Service Area “B” by Rio
Page 9
Solano County

July 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Vista Sanitation Service (Mt. Diablo Resource Recovery) and authorizing the 
processing of real property liens in accordance with Government Code section 
25831; 3) adopted Resolution No. 2025-168 confirming delinquent accounts for 
solid waste services provided in unincorporated Solano County Service Area 
“C” by Solano Garbage Company (Republic Services) and authorizing the 
processing of real property liens in accordance with Government Code section 
25831; and 4) adopted Resolution No. 2025-169 confirming delinquent accounts 
for solid waste services provided in unincorporated Solano County Service 
Area “E” by Recology Vallejo and authorizing the processing of real property 
liens in accordance with Government Code section 25831; 5) approved a $62 
administrative charge per parcel for County departments to recover costs; 6) 
directed the Clerk of the Board to file a certified copy of the resolutions with 
the County Recorder creating liens against the parcels contained in the 
confirmed Report of Delinquent Solid Waste Accounts; 7) authorized the 
Auditor-Controller to impose the delinquent fees and administrative charges as 
special assessments on the FY2025/26 property tax roll; and 8) authorized the 
Director of Resource Management, or designee, to record a Release of Lien 
when delinquent accounts are paid. So ordered by a 4-0 vote with Supervisor 
Vasquez absent. (see Resolution Book)

chunks.item_title: Receive
chunks.text:
Receive 
an 
update 
from 
Resource 
Management 
on 
a 
request 
from 
Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District to conduct a comprehensive study related to 
current and future sewer service requests in the Suisun Valley; Provide 
direction to staff on next steps to facilitate this request including authorizing 
staff to initiate engagement with the Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District to develop 
a scope of work for resource sharing agreements with qualified engineering 
consultants to facilitate the comprehensive study
A - 2280 Rockville Service Request - Letter to Solano County
B - Woodcreek 60 Service Request - Letter to Solano County
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item and 
provided a brief overview of the Suisun Valley Strategic Plan.
Water and Natural Resources Program Manager Misty Kaltreider provided an 
overview of the infrastructure limitations of the Suisun Valley. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the necessity to 
complete multiple comprehensive sewer studies before the Woodcreek 60 or 
Rockville Road parcels can be added to the Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District, 
Mr. Bezek stated there is only a need to complete one comprehensive study.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the lack of 
stakeholder engagement, County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the Board 
provided direction to staff to bifurcate the projects, noting staff went forward 
with the two separate projects as directed by the Board, with plans for a 
parallel track for stakeholder outreach. Ms. Curry further stated the 
Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District then refused to move forward with the projects 
until a comprehensive study is completed. 
Supervisor Williams, referencing minutes from a previous meeting, pointed 
Page 10
Solano County

July 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
out stakeholder involvement was supposed to be completed prior to starting 
the study, stating she will not support the recommended action due to a lack 
of stakeholder participation.
A lengthy discussion was held regarding stakeholder participation during the 
comprehensive study. 
Chair Mashburn stated staff has no intention of not completing stakeholder 
outreach, noting they simply are planning on doing it as part of the 
comprehensive study instead of before.
Discussion was held regarding the parcels that have already been approved 
for connection, but are being held up by the Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District 
until a comprehensive study has been completed. 
Fairfield Suisun Sewer District General Manager Jordan Damerel stated it is 
currently illegal for sewer services to be provided to the Suisun Valley 
because it goes against the Sewer District Enabling Act, which includes 
some of the Woodcreek 60 parcels and the 2280 Rockville Road parcel. Mr. 
Damerel further stated the Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District needs to look at 
these projects holistically instead of bifurcating them to better plan for the 
future. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding potential projects 
in District 2, Mr. Damerel stated the Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District is required 
by law to plan for areas that are already identified as part of the Fairfield’s 
sphere of influence which could be annexed in the future. Mr. Damerel further 
stated the areas for today's item have not been designated in a city's sphere 
of influence. Mr. Damerel further stated the Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District 
needs to have a better understanding of what the County's plan is holistically 
for sewer service before they can evaluate what legislative options exist to 
change the Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District boundaries. Mr. Damerel further 
stated the Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District is only asking for a review of the 
areas that are going to funnel into Cordelia so they can ensure their planned 
upgrades will be adequately sized for future development. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding when the 
Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District advised the County it would require a 
comprehensive study, Mr. Damerel stated it was March 2025.
In response to Mr. Damerel's comments Supervisor Williams stated there 
was ample time to begin the process of working with the stakeholders and 
restated she will be voting no on this item because the stakeholders were not 
met with ahead of time. 
County Administrator Bill Emlen stated after receiving the information from the 
Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District staff realized before spending time on this 
issue, it was necessary to return to the Board to receive further direction 
before engaging the stakeholders. Mr. Emlen further stated there are many 
dimensions to this issue; however, there is going to be an investment by the 
County in this process, so Board direction was necessary.
Page 11
Solano County

July 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public 
to address the Board on this matter and the following comments were 
received:
A) Duane Kromm commented in support of delaying the recommended study
until the General Plan process takes place.
B) Jim Leland commented in support of delaying the recommended study
until the Sustainable Agricultural Lands Conservation (SALC) Infrastructure
Committee meets again in September 2025.
C) Cliff Howard commented in support of delaying the recommended study
until the SALC Infrastructure Committee meets again in September 2025 and
commented in support of staff utilizing the Farm Bureau and several other
stakeholder groups for future outreach.
D) Lisa Howard stated there are no requests for sewer services in the Suisun
Valley and commented in support of delaying the recommended study until
the SALC Infrastructure Committee meets again in September 2025.
E) Don Hofer commented in support of the County moving forward with the
comprehensive review.
F) Tamara Gerlach commented in opposition to municipal sewer services
within

chunks.text:

enforcement assistance to the City of Vallejo; Provide direction on a proposed 
contract for services; and, If applicable, consider delegating authority to the 
County 
Administrator,

County 
Counsel

Services

to

any 
necessary

to 
the

Contracting and Purchasing Policy in order to expedite related purchases
A - Term Sheet
B - DSA Letter - Dated June 17, 2025
C - Draft Contract Vallejo Law Enforcement Services
Attachments:
Sheriff Tom Ferrara introduced the item and provided an update on steps 
completed on the City of Vallejo Law Enforcement Assistance contract. 
Sheriff Ferrara further stated he and staff met with the Deputy Sheriff’s 
Association (DSA), but they have not yet come to an agreement and another 
meet and confer with the DSA is necessary. Sheriff Ferrara further stated he 
believes they are close to receiving a final answer from DSA and should be 
able to return to the Board on August 5, 2025 with a final answer.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter and the following comments were received:
A) City of Vallejo Mayor Andrea Sorce commented in support of the contract.
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board: 
1) delegated authority to the County Administrator to approve any necessary
exemptions to the County Purchasing Policy in order to facilitate the purchase
of the necessary vehicles and equipment in relation to the temporary law
enforcement services contract between the City of Vallejo and the Sheriff's
Department; and 2) continued discussion of the contract to the August 5, 2025.
So ordered by a 4-0 vote with Supervisor Vasquez absent.
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports 
on meetings. The following comments were received:
Page 14
Solano County

July 22, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
A) Supervisor James commented on the City of Vallejo 707 Week, noting it
was very successful and well attended by the residents and local businesses.
Supervisor James further stated the Working Waterfront Coalition will be
celebrating its third graduation on Friday, July 25, 2025.
B) Supervisor Brown commented on House Resolution 1, noting there will be
significant cuts to funding for the SNAP program as well as adding work
requirements being put in place for those adults 18-64 who have children over
the age of 13.
C) Supervisor Williams requested that this meeting of the Solano County
Board of Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Former Suisun City Council
Member Jane Day and Retired Suisun Fire Protection District Commissioner
Warren Sheldon.
ADJOURN:

P.M. Next meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors will be August
5, 2025 at 9:00 A.M., Board Chambers, 675 Texas Street, Fairfield,
California.

ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
This is your opportunity to address the Board on a matter not listed on the Agenda; 
however, items must be within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. Please 
submit a Speaker Card before the first speaker is called and limit your comments to 3 
minutes. The Board will hear public comments for up to 15 minutes. Any additional 
public comments will be heard at the conclusion of the meeting. Items from the public 
will be taken under consideration without discussion by the Board and may be referred to 
staff.

Each speaker shall have 3 minutes to address any or all items on the Consent Calendar.
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
The Board considers all matters listed under the Consent Calendar to be 
non-controversial or routine and will adopt them in one motion. There will be no 
discussion on these items before the Board votes on the motion unless Board members 
request specific items be discussed and/or removed from the Consent Calendar.

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation from MES Consultants, LLC. on the results of
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation from MES Consultants, LLC. on the results of 
Listening Tours conducted as part of the Inclusive Leadership Program
A - Listening Tour Power Point
Attachments:
Assistant County Administrator Debbie Vaughn introduced the item. 
Consultant for MES Concepts LLC Mary Stutts provided an overview of the 
listening tour completed with Solano County employees and provided an overview 
of potential best practices for the County going forward. 
County Administrator Bill Emlen thanked Ms. Stutts for her presentation noting it 
is important to understand staff’s perceptions of the County. Mr. Emlen further 
stated the County needs to revisit its strategies surrounding remote work and 
examine how the County communicates as a whole organization.
Chair Mashburn commented on the various recommendations, noting some of 
the recommendations might have a considerable fiscal impact on the County. 
Chair Mashburn noted while some recommendations can be immediately 
addressed such as countywide communication, other recommendations will 
require significant staff time for research or will need to be discussed as part of 
labor negotiations. 
In response to Chair Mashburn’s comments, Ms. Stutts stated the next step in 
the process are planned management workshops where employee perceptions 
will 
be 
discussed 
in 
order 
to 
facilitate 
better 
communication 
between 
management and the employees. 
Supervisor Williams thanked Ms. Stutts for the presentation.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding second chance 
hiring, Ms. Stutts stated second chance hiring is the hiring of employees who are 
retired and are looking to start a second career, hiring of a mother who is 
returning to work after raising children, or hiring someone who has a criminal 
record and is looking to return to the workforce. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the idea of 
innovative benefits, Ms. Stutts stated employees are now looking for benefits that 
are different from what has been traditionally offered in the past. Ms. Stutts further 
stated these benefits could include upskilling and having the ability to obtain 
additional certifications, offering the ability for employees to take a sabbatical or 
offering more personalized benefits like pet insurance or an onsite cafeteria.
Page 6
Solano County

August 5, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding clarification of 
community involvement, Ms. Stutts stated County employees indicated in 
interviews that as both residents and employees of Solano County, they desire to 
have the ability to engage with their community more.
Chair Mashburn commented on upcoming events with the Sheriff’s Department 
where the Board Members can attend.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
Received
19

chunks.item_title: Receive
chunks.text:
Receive 
the 
2024 Solano 
County 
Crop 
and 
Livestock 
Report 
from 
the 
Agricultural Commissioner/Sealer of Weights and Measures 
A - Link to the 2024 Crop and Livestock Report
B - PowerPoint Presentation
Attachments:
Agricultural Commissioner/Sealer of Weights and Measures Ed King introduced 
the item and provided a brief history of Solano County’s agricultural past. 
Assistant 
Agricultural 
Commissioner/Assistant 
Sealer 
of 
Weights 
Priscilla 
Yeaney provided an overview of the County’s 2024 top agricultural crops. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding what the alfalfa crop 
is utilized for and why the annual sales have decreased, Mr. King stated the 
County’s alfalfa crop is used for animal feed, noting the overall amount harvested 
has been pretty consistent; however, prices had inflated due to Solano County 
not facing the same water shortage as other areas of the State of California. Mr. 
King further stated the prices have simply returned to their pre-inflation rates.
Chair Mashburn commented on the lifespan of agricultural crops, noting there will 
be ups and downs in the values and demand.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding if there has been a 
decrease in demand for walnuts, Mr. King stated in contrast to almonds which 
are primarily only grown in California, walnuts are grown in many places of the 
world which leads to more competition. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding the removal of a crop, 
Mr. King stated the removal of an orchard is easy because the trees can be 
chipped up; however, removal of an vineyard can result in a significant amount 
clean up being necessary. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need for the County to concentrate more on 
biomass industries coming into the region. 
Deputy Agricultural Commissioner/Deputy Sealer of Weights Matthew Carl 
provided an overview of exportation of Solano County agricultural products and 
Page 7
Solano County

August 5, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
the certification of farmer’s markets in Solano County. 
Chair Mashburn thanked staff for the presentation
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter. There was no public comment.
Received

9:30 A.M.
RECONVENE
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors reconvened at 9:45 
A.M. All members were present and Chair Mashburn presided.
REPORT OF ACTION IN CLOSED SESSION (IF APPLICABLE)
Chair Mashburn announced on a vote of 3-2 the Board of Supervisors 
appointed Carrie Blacklock to the position of County Counsel and Ms. 
Blacklock will assume the position upon the retirement of Bernadette Curry.
SALUTE TO THE FLAG AND A MOMENT OF SILENCE
This meeting of the Solano County Board of Supervisors continued with the 
Salute to the Flag and a Moment of Silence.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on matters 
not listed on the agenda but within the subject matter jurisdiction of the Board. 
The following comments were received:
A) James Schneider commented on concerns about industrial zoning and
County liability.
B) Steve Olry commented on issues with individuals who are released from
County jails settling in the City of Suisun and the need for wrap around
services for those being released from jail.
C) Joel Barrilleaux commented on opposition to the California Forever project.
ADDITIONS TO OR DELETIONS FROM THE AGENDA
There were no additions to or deletions from the Solano County Board of 
Supervisors' agenda for August 12, 2025.
APPROVAL OF THE AGENDA
On motion of Supervisor Williams, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
approved the agenda of the Solano County Board of Supervisors for August 
12, 2025 as submitted. So ordered by a 5-0 vote.
PUBLIC COMMENT ON CONSENT CALENDAR
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on items 
listed on the Consent Calendar. There was no public comment.
Page 2
Solano County

August 12, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
APPROVAL OF THE CONSENT CALENDAR
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
approved the following Consent Calendar items by 5-0 vote:

chunks.item_title: Acknowledge
chunks.text:
Acknowledge 
notice 
from 
Thomas 
A. 
Ferrara, 
Solano 
County 
Sheriff/Coroner, 
of 
his 
retirement 
effective 
September 
25, 
2025; 
and 
Consider appointing Undersheriff Brad DeWall to serve the remainder of the 
unexpired term of Solano County Sheriff/Coroner
A - Ferrara Retirement Letter
Attachments:
Chair Mashburn thanked Sheriff/Coroner Tom Ferrara for his service to Solano 
County and the time they served together. 
Supervisor 
Williams 
thanked 
Sheriff/Coroner 
Ferrara 
and 
wished 
him 
a 
wonderful retirement. 
Sheriff/Coroner Ferrara thanked the Board for their kind words and stated he 
has 
enjoyed 
his 
time 
as 
Sheriff 
and 
commented 
on 
the 
different 
accomplishments of his office. 
County Administrator Bill Emlen introduced the item and commented on 
Sheriff/Coroner Ferrara’s service to Solano County. Mr. Emlen commented on 
the possible actions the Board can take regarding appointing a replacement for 
Sheriff/Coroner Ferrara. Mr. Emlen stated the Board can choose to do public 
interviews. 
Mr. 
Emlen 
commented 
on 
the 
County 
Administrator’s 
recommendation for the appointment of Undersheriff Brad DeWall, noting during 
Undersheriff DeWall's long career with the Sheriff’s Department he has worked 
in all areas of the office. 
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A)
Joshua Patzer commented in opposition to the Board appointment of
Undersheiff DeWall, and in support of an open process for appointing the new
Sheriff/Coroner.
B)
Jeremie Patzer commented in opposition to the Board appointment of
Undersheiff DeWall, and in support of an open process for appointing the new
Sheriff/Coroner.
C)
Christine Dean commented in opposition to the Board appointment of
Undersheiff DeWall, and in support of an open process for appointing the new
Sheriff/Coroner.
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the law does not allow for a mid-cycle 
election. Ms. Curry further stated since there is no option for the Board to call for 
an election the position can only be filled by either an appointment by the Board 
Page 4
Solano County

August 12, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
or the Undersheriff automatically assumes the office until the next election. Ms. 
Curry further stated, it was not the County that added two additional years to the 
Sheriff/Coroner term, noting the addition was done by the State of California 
Legislature. 
Supervisor Williams stated she 100% believes Undersheriff DeWall is more than 
qualified to be the new Sheriff/Coroner; however, she is in support of an open 
interview process for the position of the Sheriff/Coroner. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the County’s use of succession planning with 
regard to the Auditor/Controller, noting that there will be an election for this 
position in 3 years and at that time the citizens will have the ability to elect a new 
Sheriff/Coroner if they desire to do so. Supervisor Brown commented on 
upcoming changes in many departments, noting Undersheriff DeWall will bring 
consistency to the role of Sheriff/Coroner. 
Supervisor Williams commented on consistency, noting there needs to be a 
policy in place that addresses vacancies, particularly for elected positions. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Brown, the Board: 
1) acknowledged receipt of notice from Sheriff Thomas A. Ferrara of his
retirement from the Office of Solano County Sheriff/Coroner, effective
September 25, 2025; and 2) appointed Undersheriff, Brad DeWall to serve the
remainder of the unexpired term as Solano County Sheriff/Coroner, effective at
5:00 p.m. on September 25, 2025. So ordered by a 3-2 vote with Supervisor
James and Supervisor Williams voting no.
7

(CEQA) 
A - Resolution w/ Exhibit A

H - Draft Contract 1393

Attachments:
Planning Manager Allan Calder introduced the item. 
Page 5
Solano County

August 12, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Principal Planner Mathew Walsh provided an overview of the minor subdivision 
application noting the process has been complicated because approval of the 
application will mean the contracts will no longer follow the property lines in the 
existing Williamson Act contracts and as a result new Williamson contracts will 
be required. Mr. Walsh noted adding to the complexity of the application, is the 
fact that the property is not adjacent to the project; therefore in order to gain 
approval multiple signatures were required. 
Consulting Planner Kathy Pease provided a brief history of the project noting the 
resulting subdivision will meet all zoning requirements of being over 40 acres. 
Ms. Pease noted no significant impacts were identified that cannot be mitigated. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public to
address the Board on this matter and the following comments were received:
A) Representative of the landowners Grant Guerri commented in support of the
project.
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the requested 
action to rescind the old Williamson Act contracts and approving new Williamson 
Act contracts Ms. Pease provided an overview of the Williamson Act contract 
process. 
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor Williams, the 
Board: 1) adopted Resolution No. 2025-182 approving Minor Subdivision 
Application No. MS-24-02 of Realized Dreams to subdivide four (4) existing 
parcels totaling 426± acres, into ten (10) agricultural lots, over 41± acres each, 
APNs 110-190-09, 110-190-10, 111-070-20, 111-070-21, including actions and 
findings that: a) adopted a Mitigated Negative Declaration, pursuant to the 
California Environmental Quality Act; b) approved Minor Subdivision 
application MS-24-02 to allow a Minor Subdivision of four (4) existing parcels 
totaling 426± acres, into ten (10) agricultural lots, over 41± acres each; c) 
rescinded Land Conservation contract Nos. 14 and 15; and d) approved 
replacement Land Conservation contract Nos. 1391, 1392, and 1393. So 
ordered by a 5-0 vote.
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-182
8

chunks.item_title: Receive a presentation on the status of the draft Battery Energy Storage
chunks.text:
Receive a presentation on the status of the draft Battery Energy Storage 
System (BESS) ordinance; Provide feedback and direction on proposed 
ordinance provisions; Direct staff to proceed with final ordinance preparation 
and public hearing scheduling
A - BESS Ordinance - DRAFT
B - ERP Guidance - DRAFT
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item.
Associate Planner Erik Hagstrom provided an overview of the Board’s past 
Page 6
Solano County

August 12, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
actions regarding Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS), on the proposed 
BESS project locations, and on the process used by the Department of 
Resource Management to create the draft ordinance. 
Planning Manager Allan Calder reminded the Board that the applicants have the 
option to bypass local regulations and go to the State of California (State) to get 
approval of BESS projects. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the requirements that the State take local 
policies 
or 
ordinances 
under 
consideration 
when 
looking 
at 
approving 
applications for BESS facilities. 
In response to Chair Mashburn’s comments, Mr. Bezek stated the current 
applications that have been deemed incomplete were deemed so because of 
comments submitted to the State by County staff.
Supervisor Brown voiced concerns over the possibility of agricultural lands being 
no longer usable as a result of an accident at the site, noting that is the current 
outcome of the Moss Landing incident. Supervisor Brown commented on her 
concerns over the applicants’ ability take their application to the State, bypassing 
County land use policies to obtain approval for projects. Supervisor Brown 
voiced concerns over the safety of Solano County’s residents, noting the 
ordinance adopted by the Board needs to be as tight as it can be. Supervisor 
Brown recommended staff contact Solano County’s State representatives about 
changing this policy. Supervisor Brown further recommended funding for extra 
help for the fire department and other first responders be a part of the conditions 
of approval for future applications. 
In response to comments made by Supervisor Vasquez regarding the current 
process creating a double standard, Mr. Bezek stated that is the balancing act 
staff is walking in creating a draft ordinance that protects Solano County but is 
not overly restrictive, noting an overly restrictive ordinance would potentially 
encourage applicants to bypass the County and go to the State for approval of 
their project. Mr. Bezek further stated systems built like the one at Moss Landing 
are no longer eligible to be approved, noting the goal of future systems is 
utilizing lessons that were learned from the incident at Moss Landing to keep it 
from happening again.
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding decommissioning 
of a site, Mr. Hagstrom stated the decommissioning process requires applicants 
to provide a financial commitment and a guarantee to completely restore the 
property, noting 50% of the financial commitment must be posted by the start of 
full commercial operation and 100% posted by the 5th year of operations. Mr. 
Hagstrom further stated payment can include insurance for bankruptcy in the 
form of a bridge policy and shall include but is not limited to financial assurance 
in the form of a bond, a parent company guarantee or an irrevocable letter of 
credit. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Vasquez regarding if the County 
Page 7
Solano County

August 12, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
chooses which form of guaranteed payment will be made, Mr. Hagstrom stated 
the applicant can choose which option to take. 
Supervisor Vasquez commented on the need for a review of the application with 
regard to the decommissioning process, noting it should go before the Debt 
Advisory Board. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the need to ensure that there is no burden on 
the County for the provision of safety equipment and safety training, noting it 
needs to be required that they pay for these items prior to beginning a project 
including the bond for decommissioning. Supervisor Brown commented on the 
need to keep the BESS facilities away from schools. 
In response to comments from Supervisor Brown, Mr. Bezek stated the 
ordinance they are crafting does have those requirements within it. Mr. Bezek 
further stated staff has consulted with the fire district and other first responders 
to obtain a list of concerns and requirements. Mr. Bezek further stated staff has 
conveyed that information to the California Energy Commission (CEC), with a 
goal to roll the requirements into what the CEC approves as well. Mr. Bezek 
further stated staff will work on adding the requirements for the equipment that 
the fire districts and first responders will need, who pays for that and when, and 
training 
and 
other 
methodologies 
which 
falls 
somewhat 
under 
a 
quasi-community benefit and is also a mitigation requirement in order to show it 
is a safe and proper process. 
Mr. Hagstrom commented on additional proposed safety standards within the 
ordinance. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the need to bring in the hospitals into the 
conversation on what may be needed if there is an incident that requires health 
care. 
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated there is an option of complete 
prohibition of approval of BESS systems on agricultural lands.
Mr. Bezek stated while a complete ban in agricultural areas is an option; it would 
not preclude companies from bypassing the County and going to the State to get 
approval of the application. 
Discussion was held regarding direction from the Board of the provided options 
for placement on prime ag land, set back requirements, proposed exclusions, 
and draft ordinance exemptions and mitigations requirements. 
In response to comments from Chair Mashburn regarding the possibility of an 
application bypassing the County because the applicant

chunks.item_title: Receive an update on the Sheriff Office’s ability to provide temporary law
chunks.text:
Receive an update on the Sheriff Office’s ability to provide temporary law 
enforcement assistance to the City of Vallejo; and Provide direction on a 
proposed contract for services
A - Vallejo Term Sheet
B - Vallejo DSA Letter
C - Draft Contract Vallejo Law Enforcement Services
Attachments:
Sheriff/Coroner Tom Ferrara introduced the item, provided an overview of steps 
that have been taken to provide temporary law enforcement assistance to the 
City of Vallejo, and requested the Board consider continuing the item to August 
26, 2025.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this
matter and the following comments were received:
A) Jason Ackley commented in support of the contract.
Page 12
Solano County

August 12, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
B) Ryan Wallace commented on the ongoing meet and confer process with the
Deputy Sheriff’s Association (DSA) and voiced concerns of the DSA that critical
staffing issues that remain unresolved.
ITEMS FROM THE PUBLIC con't
There were no additional comments from the public. 
BOARD MEMBER COMMENTS AND REPORTS ON MEETINGS
Chair Mashburn invited members of the Board to make comments or reports on
meetings. The following comments were received:
A) Supervisor James offered congratulations to Vallejo native CC Sabathia on
his recent induction into the Major League Baseball Hall of Fame. Supervisor
James commented on the ending of her office’s summer intern program, noting
the program provided the interns with a front row seat to the work being done in
District 1 and in Solano County. Supervisor James further stated that her interns
were 
able 
to 
contribute 
to 
internal 
operations, 
infrastructure, 
community
engagement efforts and planning and supporting public events.
B) Supervisor Brown commented on the beginning of the school year and
requested drivers remember to slow down in school zones. Supervisor Brown
asked staff about the McCormack Hall project that was funded with ARPA
funding.
In response to Supervisor Brown’s questions, County Administrator Bill Emlen
stated the project will be completed by the end of the year. 
C) Supervisor Williams commented on the ending of her office’s summer intern
program, noting her intern contributed to an initiative that District 3 will be
launching soon, noting she is hopeful her intern will come back to work for
Solano County.
D) Chair Mashburn requested that this meeting of the Solano County Board of
Supervisors be adjourned in memory of Patrick Bidou.

chunks.item_title: Receive
chunks.text:
Receive 
a 
presentation 
on 
potential 
social 
safety 
net 
program 
impacts 
resulting from H.R. 1, signed on July 4, 2025 and the FY2025/26 California 
State budget 
A - Link to HR 1 Files
Attachments:
Assistant 
County 
Administrator 
Debbie 
Vaughn 
introduced 
the 
item 
and 
provided an overview of the potential impacts to the County’s social safety net 
programs resulting from the adoption of H.R. 1 and the Fiscal Year 2025/26 
State of California (State) budget.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the waiting 
period for legal permanent residents to obtain CalFresh benefits, Ms. Vaughn 
stated there is now a five year waiting period.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding changes to the 
formula used to calculate CalFresh benefits, Ms. Vaughn stated the standard 
utility 
and 
internet 
allowances 
have 
been 
removed 
from 
the 
formula 
calculations.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the loss of 
funding for SnapEd programing for the Area Agency on Aging and Public 
Health resulting in potential layoffs, Ms. Vaughn stated those individuals that 
Page 8
Solano County

August 26, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
have job classifications that are used elsewhere within Public Health will be 
transferred into new programs where available. Ms. Vaughn further stated that 
this does mean that there will not be additional employees hired for Public 
Health, which is an indirect attrition of Public Health.
Assistant Director of Health and Social Services Kelley Curtis provided an 
overview of Medicaid and State Medi-Cal changes as a result of H.R. 1 and 
changes made by the State.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding who has legal 
residency, 
Ms. 
Curtis 
stated 
legal 
permanent 
residents, 
Cuban-Haitian 
immigrants, and those part of the Compact of Free Association which is the 
Marshall Islands as well as some other smaller island nations.
Supervisor 
Brown 
voiced 
concerns 
over 
the 
potential 
loss 
of 
medical 
insurance and the potential outcomes that could happen to individuals who 
end up with large hospital bills.
In 
response 
to 
a 
question 
from 
Supervisor 
Vasquez 
regarding 
what 
constitutes work or education hours, Ms. Curtis said, having a certain number 
of hours in college, in the workforce, or volunteer hours.
In response to a question from Supervisor James regarding if the 62 and over 
population that are part of the Non-MAGI (Modified Adjusted Gross Income) 
Medi-Cal will also have copays in addition to their share of cost, Ms. Vaughn 
stated Non-MAGI will have a copay on top of their share of cost. 
Ms. 
Vaughn 
provided 
an 
overview 
of 
upcoming 
changes 
to 
Covered 
California.
Supervisor Brown requested staff return with updates as more information 
comes in. 
Supervisor 
Williams 
commented 
in 
support 
of 
Supervisor 
Brown’s 
comments. 
In response to a question from Chair Mashburn regarding if definitions of 
volunteer or service hours or what constitutes an educational program have 
been provided, Ms. Curtis stated not at this time, but she is certain the State 
will invest in some sort of programming to meet the needs. 
Chair Mashburn commented in favor of the County creating a volunteer and 
education program so that as individuals are signing up for services, they can 
be enrolled in one of the programs. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the potential creation of an Ad-hoc committee 
of two Board members and representatives from the local hospitals to 
discuss possible safety net programs.
Page 9
Solano County

August 26, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
24

chunks.item_title: There was consensus of the Board for Chair Mashburn to return with an item
chunks.text:
There was consensus of the Board for Chair Mashburn to return with an item 
in September related to the creation of an Ad-hoc committee. 
Supervisor Brown stated the County should look for possible inexpensive 
education options for individuals to meet the work/education requirements. 
Supervisor James requested Touro University be added to the Ad-hoc 
committee hospital representatives. 
In response to a question from Supervisor James regarding exemptions, Ms. 
Curtis stated homeless veterans and those coming out of foster care are no 
longer exempt from the work/education requirements.
Chair Mashburn invited members of the public to address the Board on this 
matter. There was no public comment.
Received

Collector 
Denise 
Dix 
introduced 
the 
item 
and 
provided an overview of the requested action. 
Vice President for Real Estate and Government Affairs for NorthBay Health 
Chris Matthews provided comments related to the requested action.
Financial Advisor for the California Municipal Finance Authority (CMFA) Jarod 
Suzuki stated approval by the Board will not result in additional debt for 
Solano County.
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding the buildings in 
Winters and Rio Vista, which had been purchased by California Forever, Mr. 
Matthews stated NorthBay Health is currently rehabbing both buildings at a 
tremendous cost as well as paying rent on the buildings to California Forever. 
Discussion was held regarding why this item is appearing before the Board of 
Supervisors and how the bonds will work.
Page 10
Solano County

August 26, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the financing of 
the two buildings, Mr. Matthews provided an explanation, noting they will be 
purchasing the buildings from California Forever, and will be entering into a 
structured lease agreement with two other owners. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public 
to address the Board on this matter and the following comments were 
received:
A) Gaul Culley commented in opposition to the recommended action.
County Counsel Bernadette Curry stated the Board does not have jurisdiction 
over how NorthBay Health wants to structure the buildings, noting by approval 
of the recommended action, the Board is stating that there is a public benefit 
associated with what NorthBay Health desires to do and the Board is simply 
giving the administrative approval to allow NorthBay Health to move forward 
with CMFA to issues the bonds.
Chair Mashburn closed the public hearing.
On motion of Supervisor Vasquez, seconded by Supervisor James, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2025-189 approving the issuance of revenue bonds by 
the California Municipal Finance Authority (CMFA), in an amount not to exceed 
$20,000,000 for the purpose of financing and/or refinancing certain costs of the 
acquisition, construction, expansion, remodeling, renovation, furnishing, 
equipping and/or improvement of the health facilities, including real estate, 
owned and operated by HealthCore 2460 Hilborn Fairfield, LLC, HealthCore 
2458 Hilborn Fairfield, LLC and HealthCore Rio Vista, LLC (collectively, the 
“Borrowers”) and leased to NorthBay Group and/or NorthBay Corporation, 
located within Solano County. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-189
25

chunks.text:
Conduct a noticed public hearing to consider approving Minor Subdivision 
application MS-25-01 by Darlene Foon Lum, Trustee of the Darlene F. Lum 
Trust dated April 3, 2024, and Charles F. Lum Family Limited Partnership to 
subdivide a 41.17-acre property under Land Conservation Contract No. 1199 
into two parcels of 21.15 and 20.02 acres, located along Rockville Road, one 
mile west of the City of Fairfield, within the Suisun Valley Agriculture 
“A-SV-20” zoning district, APN’s 0027-030-150 and 0027-251-280; the project 
is exempt from the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) pursuant to 
§15061(b)(3) of the CEQA Guidelines because it has been determined that 
the proposed project will not have the potential to cause a significant effect on 
the environment
A - Resolution
B - Tentative Parcel Map
C - Williamson Act Contract No. 1199
D - Public Hearing Notice
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item. 
Page 11
Solano County

August 26, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Supervisor Vasquez stated the reason this item is coming before the Board 
for approval is because the property is under a Williamson Act contract. 
Senior Planner Eric Wilberg provided an overview of the project and the 
recommended action. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding why there was 
a failure to record the lot line adjustment that was previously approved, Mr. 
Wilberg stated he believes it is because there were some issues with the 
sale of the lot or acreage. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Brown regarding why this has 
returned to the Board, Mr. Wilberg stated this action will create a stand-alone 
buildable lot, whereas the previous approval was for a lot line adjustment to 
allow 20 acres of land to merge with the Bane property.
Chair Mashburn opened and closed the public hearing with no comments
from the public. 
On motion of Chair Mashburn, seconded by Supervisor Vasquez, the Board 
adopted Resolution No. 2025-190 approving Minor Subdivision No. MS-25-01 by 
the Lum Family Limited Partnership to subdivide a 41.17-acre property under 
Land Conservation (Williamson Act) contract No. 1199 into two parcels of 21.15 
and 20.02 acres, located along Rockville Road, one mile west of the City of 
Fairfield, within the Suisun Valley Agricultural “A-SV-20” zoning district, APN’s 
0027-030-150 and 0027-251-280. So ordered by a 5-0 vote. (see Resolution Book)
Enactment No: Resolution No. 2025-190

chunks.item_title: Hold a noticed Public Hearing to consider amending interim Ordinance No.
chunks.text:
Hold a noticed Public Hearing to consider amending interim Ordinance No. 
2024-1852-U-E 
limiting 
new 
commercial 
battery 
energy 
storage 
systems 
within the unincorporated territory of the County of Solano (4/5 vote required); 
the proposed amendment is not subject to the California Environmental 
Quality Act (CEQA) pursuant to section 15060(c)(2), and is exempt under 
Sections 15061(b)(3), 15307, and 15308 of the CEQA Guidelines
A - Ordinance 2024-1852-U-E Amendment 1 - Clean
B - Ord 2024-1852-U-E Amendment 1 - redline
C - Adopted Interim Ordinance
D - Public Notice
Attachments:
Director of Resource Management James Bezek introduced the item. 
Associate 
Planner 
Erik 
Hagstrom 
provided 
an 
overview 
of 
the 
current 
recommendations for a Battery Energy Storage Systems 
(BESS) interim 
Page 12
Solano County

August 26, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
ordinance amendment. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the locations of 
the 
recommended 
industrial 
and 
manufacturing 
districts 
where 
BESS 
facilities can be located, Mr. Bezek stated there are 44 parcels that have been 
identified. 
County 
Counsel 
Bernadette 
Curry 
stated 
the 
location 
of 
the 
manufacturing and industrial zoned properties can be found in the land use 
designation map Figure LU-1 on page LU-7 of the General Plan.
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the distance 
between the identified location on the Lambie property, voicing concerns over 
planned housing from the City of Suisun and the California Forever project as 
well as potential impacts to Travis AFB, Mr. Bezek stated the ordinance 
addresses existing housing, not planned housing. Mr. Bezek further stated 
anyone who will be looking to build housing in this location will already be 
aware that this area is zoned for industrial uses, not just BESS facilities but 
other industrial uses that will have an impact on residential areas. Mr. Bezek 
further stated the final ordinance has the potential for battery storage facilities 
that are compatible in the sense that the potential restrictions won’t be as 
strict.
A discussion period was held regarding the potential impacts of placing a 
BESS facility at the Lambie location.
Ms. Curry stated staff has brought forward a zoning ordinance, noting at this 
time the County has a complete ban on BESS facilities. Ms. Curry further 
stated staff took feedback provided by the Board and amended the ordinance 
to allow BESS facilities in very specific locations with certain approval 
processes associated with a final approval of a facility. Ms. Curry noted there 
is more work to be done prior to the final ordinance being brought forward to 
the Board. Ms. Curry further stated staff is trying to strike a balance to ensure 
that applicants will not simply bypass the County process and seek approval 
from the State. 
Chair Mashburn thanked staff for the work completed, noting that Solano 
cannot be the County of no because then the State will make the decision for 
the County of where BESS facilities will be located. Chair Mashburn further 
stated this ordinance will provide the County with the ability to work with the 
State to try and ensure the locations chosen by the County are the ones that 
will be used.
Supervisor Williams commented on the need for the County to review the 
plume studies to ensure there is not drift towards populated areas.
In response to comments by the Board, Mr. Bezek stated the advantage is 
that the County is not only identifying sites where BESS facilities can be 
located but the ordinance is also providing provisions and conditions for 
approval.
Page 13
Solano County

August 26, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
Ms. Curry reiterated her comments on reasons why it is important for this 
ordinance to be amended and added information regarding the process for 
approving a use permit for a BESS facility noting that any project would first 
have to go before the Planning Commission as well as come to the Board for 
approval. Ms. Curry noted that adoption of the ordinance will allow staff to 
analyze the application based on conditions that are part of this ordinance, 
which include environmental review. 
Supervisor 
Vasquez 
commented 
on 
the 
process, 
noting 
that 
identifying 
locations, the adoption of an interim ordinance, is not a new process for the 
County. 
Supervisor 
Vasquez 
further 
stated 
the 
County 
is 
providing 
an 
opportunity for an application, but at the end of the day, the Board still has final 
approval. 
Chair Mashburn opened the public hearing and invited members of the public 
to address the Board on this matter and the following comments were 
received:
A) Karen Bell commented in support of the recommended interim ordinance
amendments.
B) Gaul Culley commented in support of the recommended interim ordinance
amendments.
C) Paul Troxell commented in opposition to BESS Facilities and in support of
other energy producing facilties.
D)
Kathy Moore commented in opposition to BESS facilities in Solano
County.
E) Heidi Wood commented in support of the recommended interim ordinance
amendments.
F)
Dan 
Bouzos 
commented 
in 
support 
of 
the 
recommended 
interim
ordinance amendments.
G)
Rosie 
Stabile 
commented 
in 
support 
of 
the 
recommended 
interim
ordinance amendments and requested the final 
moratorium 
keep 
BESS
facilities off of agricultural lands and commercial zoned areas of the County.
H) Neil Serr commented in support of the recommended interim ordinance
amendments.
I) Victoria Serr commented in support of the recommended interim ordinance
amendments.
J)
Michael 
Geller 
commented 
in 
support 
of 
the 
recommended 
interim
ordinance amendments.
Page 14
Solano County

August 26, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
K) Elise Dominion commented in support of the Board extending Measure T
with a ballot in the 2026 election and provided input on possible updates to the
final ordinanc

chunks.item_title: The Department of Resource Management recommends that the Board of
chunks.text:
The Department of Resource Management recommends that the Board of 
Supervisors receive a presentation from staff on continued discussion on 
scope and issues identification for the County’s General Plan update; Provide 
feedback and direction to staff on next steps
County Administrator Bill Emlen introduced the item. 
Director of Resource Management James Bezek provided an overview of the 
2008 General Plan vision, an overview of the history of the 2008 General Plan, 
and an overview of the process to update the General Plan in relation to the 
Board’s approved priorities. 
Supervisor Brown commented on the option to potentially put in hotels in the 
vacant areas in front of the Budweiser property or the area on Chadbourne 
under Highway 12. Supervisor Brown stated the County needs to figure out 
what it needs and what development will bring more tax funding opportunities 
to the County. 
In response to Supervisor Brown’s comments, Mr. Emlen stated staff is 
looking 
at 
freeway 
interchange 
studies 
and 
looking 
at 
areas 
of 
the 
unincorporated County, some of which are already in the General Plan. 
Supervisor 
Williams 
commented 
on 
the 
need 
to 
hire 
a 
consultant 
for 
economic development as part of the General Plan update process and in 
support of a community stakeholder task force to help with the update. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need for the General Plan to focus on 
economic development specifically in the unincorporated areas of the County. 
Chair Mashburn commented in support of Supervisor Williams’s request for a 
community stakeholder task force, and in support of an infrastructure study 
being completed. 
Mr. Bezek and Mr. Emlen provided information on identifying potential sites in 
the unincorporated areas of the County for economic development. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need to look at specific plans for other 
areas of the County and on the need to look at development opportunities 
down the I-80 corridor to take advantage of the County being a transportation 
hub. 
Mr. Bezek and Mr. Emlen provided information on initiating a utility master 
Page 16
Solano County

August 26, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
plan. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need to include utility providers as part of 
the General Plan process. 
Mr. Bezek and Mr. Emlen provided information on planning and development 
of regional recreational facilities as part of the General Plan update. 
Chair 
Mashburn 
commented 
on 
the 
need 
for 
the 
County 
to 
look 
at 
public/private partnerships with parks and open spaces. Chair Mashburn 
further recommended utilizing privately held property for public access. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding housing in the 
unincorporated County, Mr. Bezek stated there are already areas in the 
unincorporated County that are pinpointed in the current General Plan for 
housing such as the Woodcreek area. Mr. Bezek further stated as the utility 
master plan study is completed, it will identify areas that the County can focus 
on for growth. 
Supervisor Vasquez provided a brief history on the use of a community task 
force for past General Plan update. A discussion period was held.
Mr. Bezek provided an overview of housing needs within the General Plan 
update. 
Chair Mashburn commented on the need to hire a consultant that can help 
the Board and the County to navigate through current legislation related to the 
creation of affordable housing within the County.
Supervisor James commented on the need to become a pro-housing county 
and stated the County should be using language that matches the language 
being used by the State of California. Supervisor James recommended the 
County begin using Area Median Income (AMI) as opposed to affordable 
housing because the term stigmatizes those individuals who are living in 
affordable housing units. 
In response to Board comments, Mr. Bezek stated at this time the 2008 
General Plan focused on housing growth in the cities, noting that part of this 
process is to understand what the Board’s goals are in relation to the 
development of housing. 
Supervisor James commented on the need to focus on how the County is 
planning on producing infrastructure and housing. 
A discussion period was held regarding housing in the County and the need to 
work with the cities.
Supervisor Vasquez requested that certain agricultural areas in the County be 
off limits for annexation by the cities and commented on the need for more 
Page 17
Solano County

August 26, 2025
Board of Supervisors
Minutes - Final
housing. 
In response to Board comments, Mr. Emlen stated the current General Plan 
focuses 
on 
density 
and 
infill 
within 
the 
cities 
before 
annexing 
prime 
agricultural lands. 
In response to a question from Supervisor Williams regarding the County 
working with Orderly Growth, Mr. Emlen stated the County will be having 
discussion with Orderly Growth, noting that key provisions of the General Plan 
are intricately tied to Measure T.
Chair Mashburn commented in support of looking at denser development 
surrounding transportation hubs, and looking for a way to incorporate other 
types of housing in areas where it is appropriate, noting that it can be trailer 
parks or small home communities, because the use of accessory dwelling 
units will not be enough to meet the Regional Housing Needs Allocation 
numbers. Chair Mashburn voiced concerns that if the County does not start 
creating this housing, the State is going to step in. 
Supervisor Brown and Supervisor Williams commented in support of small 
home communities for seniors on limited incomes.
Mr. Bezek commented on the idea of small home communities, noting that 
the current General Plan, as it is written, only allows two residences on any 
individual property.
Mr. Bezek provided an overview of the Board priority of strengthening the right 
to farm to ensure that agricultural and urban interfaces are compatible. 
Chair 
Ma
